results.description:
A three-hour tutorial on how to make your computer talk to other computers with Python. We'll learn a bit about the internet and the web and will write or modify a TCP chat client, a web server for static content, an HTTP client, and a WSGI-compliant server and web application. We will learn what all those things are and how they fit together, bringing the architecture of modern web apps into better focus.

Because space is limited, in order to attend please join the wait list and then answer a few questions at https://docs.google.com/forms/d/14Kdikbpuy8ELBxIsT6qlFZRra6n0Mf0Y-acL-bYCBFI/viewform. If there's room, your RSVP status will be changed after your response to that form is received.

Although no web development experience is necessary to attend, this tutorial may be particularly of interest to those with some web development experience that want to better understand their tools.

If you'd like to volunteer to help participants at this tutorial, send an email to [masked]

No food will be provided. Bring a wifi-capable laptop and a power cord.
results.name: Tutorial: Talking to other computers with Python

results.description:
WARNING: the meet up time now varies from week to week. if you can't make it, make sure you change your RSVP to No, such that someone else can take your spot.

We have rented 3 badminton courts at the BU Fitness & Recreation Center (regulation full sized courts).  The BU facility is immaculate and a fantastic place to play.


The fee (payable online when you RSVP) gets you into the BU Fitness & Recreation Center to play badminton for an hour and a half.  Part of the fee is for the court time and the rest is for your meetup group to cover other expenses, i.e. rackets, shuttlecocks/birdies, meetup.com fees. All fees collected go to pay the Group's expenses.

We have rackets and shuttles for everyone!

Expect to play doubles. The host can help to match up pairs but members are free to join in any game they want.  The courts are reserved only for Boston Badminton members.

Before asking a question, please read through the following FAQs:

Q: The meetup is full, can I come regardless and pay at the event?
A: No, there is limited space to make sure everyone gets to play. A few spots typically open up before the event.

Q: It's my first time, how do I find you?
A: Go to the BU Fitness & Recreation Center reception (see directions below), and tell them you're here with Boston Badminton. They'll tell you where the courts are, check you're on the list, and make you sign a waiver. The meeting point is on the courts.

Q: I am a BU student, do I get a discount?
A: No, BU charges us the same regardless of whether participants are at BU or not.


Directions:
Please click here for a google map to The BU Fitness & Recreation Center.  The easiest way to get to the FitRec center from within Boston is to take the Green Line (B)-Boston College to Saint Paul St.  Parking is limited but available.  Please click here for parking information.

Plan to grab a drink locally after if we have interest.

The club has full locker room and shower facilities.

Note: In addition to agreeing to the Meetup's Liability Waiver, all members must sign a Waiver of Liability Form in order to use BU's courts. This form is available at the front desk at the FitRec center.  We may ask you for your full name in order to help BU and the meetup comply with the liability procedures.

Let me know if you have any questions and I hope to see you there!

Liability Waiver

By attending a Boston Badminton meetup, you hereby agree to the terms of the following Liability Waiver:

The purpose of the following Liability Waiver is to protect Boston Badminton meetup members and group leaders from liability in case of accident or injury. All members must agree to the Liability Waiver in order to participate in the group and its activities.

As part of my membership to Boston Badminton on Meetup.com (hereinafter “Boston Badminton”), I hereby freely and voluntarily agree to the following Release, Acknowledgment of Risk, and Waiver of Liability:

In consideration of the opportunity to participate in events, activities, classes, and programs conducted by Boston Badminton and its affiliates in any venue, and to use equipment located therein, I, on behalf of myself and my minor children, do hereby release, hold harmless and forever discharge and agree not to sue Boston Badminton and its trustees, officers, agents, founders, members, volunteers and employees (together, "Meetup.com Group") from any and all claims, responsibilities or liabilities for injury or damages resulting from or arising out of my or my family’s use of, presence in, or participation in activities conducted at any venue rented or owned by Boston Badminton, whether or not caused by the ordinary negligence of Boston Badminton. I understand, recognize and acknowledge that certain activities conducted by Boston Badminton or taking place in venues rented or owned by Boston Badminton are potentially hazardous. I also acknowledge that it is my responsibility to follow instructions for any activity or use of equipment, and to seek help from the volunteers if I have any questions. I further understand that, notwithstanding precautions taken by Boston Badminton, sports and fitness activities involve a risk of injury and/or death. I/we are voluntarily participating in these activities and using equipment and machinery with knowledge of the dangers involved. I hereby agree to expressly assume and accept any and all risks associated with my participation in activities conducted by Boston Badminton and its affiliates. I have read the foregoing and hereby agree to be bound by same.

results.how_to_find_us: We are next door to McDonald's , parking is at the far end of the driveway, then walk up to the street then walk past the loading dock there will be a narrow entrance with  5 steps ahead the door to the studio is at the top of the steps.
results.name: Learn basic hand embroidery stitches, and use them in a creative way.

results.description:
We volunteered at Cradles to Crayons in January and had a blast, so I thought we could do it again!

Cradles to Crayons, formally launched in Boston in 2002, provides children from birth through age 12, living in homeless or low-income situations, with the essential items they need to thrive - at home, at school and at play. These items are supplied to families free of charge by engaging and connecting communities that have with communities that need. 

We will be assisting in the processing and packaging of donations. The tasks are interactive and may include sorting clothes and shoes, preparing bags, and testing toys. 

Check out the Cradles to Crayons official website for additional information and FAQs about volunteering:
http://www.cradlestocrayons.org/

Looking forward to seeing everyone there!
results.name: Cradles to Crayons

results.description:
This will be a random filler week because not a lot of people can make it. We'll still have a workout, and you're welcome to come join! Next week we'll start an endurance series.


We go across the street for pizza (or other food if you don't eat pizza) every week after the swim. Save time to join us! We usually finish up by about 4:30pm.


---------------


The pool opens at 2pm, so we meet to go in at 1:45 so that we can be out on the pool deck by 2. $6 to get in, Cambridge residents $5 (or you can buy a 10-pack for an approximate 10% discount, and we do these weekly so you'll have the opportunity to use them up).

Street parking is available but stressful, and the 69 bus drops off down the block, or you can bike or run there and do 2/3 of a triathlon :)

results.description:
Winter is on it's way out as temperatures warm and birds being returning to the city. Come and join us as we explore the Arnold Arboretum and get to know the many varieties of medicinal tree species growing in Boston.

This time of year, other medicinal plants have passed by and are waiting for the spring to come. Medicinal trees may have lost their leaves, however there are barks and evergreen needles that can still be harvested and made into teas, syrups, tinctures, salves and lotions. Pine, oak, birch, and many, many more species will be discussed, as well as their different preparations and medicinal virtues.

We will be meeting in front of the Hunnewell Visitor’s Center near the main entrance to the Arnold Arboretum, located at 125 the Arborway in Jamaica Plain. A map of our meeting point can be found here: https://www.google.com/maps?ll=42.304961,-71.121891&z=14&t=m&hl=en&gl=US&mapclient=embed&q=125+Arborway+Boston,+MA+02130

In case of heavy rain, the walk will be rescheduled. If there is light rain or flurries of snow, we will still meet and walk!

The fee for this class is $10. Please rsvp by emailing [masked], or by calling (857) 615-7763.

Saturday, March 26th, 2016
2:00 – 3:30 pm
By the Hunnewell Visitor’s Center
Arnold Arboretum, Boston
results.name: Medicinal Tree Identification Walk

results.description:
For our next book we decided to circle back to our first book so give opportunity to those interested in reading it.    

The World Peace Diet by Dr. Will Tuttle.  Will is from Concord! So fitting that we should talk about his book at the Concord library.  : )

I have an extra copy or two if anyone would like to borrow the book.  Just send me an email and we can make it happen.

Here is some more info about the book:

"The World Peace Diet, which became a #1 Amazon best-seller in March, 2010, offers a compelling and liberating new understanding of our food and our culture. It has been called one of the most important books of the 21st century: the foundation of a new society based on the truth of the interconnectedness of all life. It is the first book to make explicit the invisible connections between our culture, our food, and the source of our broad range of problems—and the way to a positive transformation in our individual and collective lives. 


The World Peace Diet is an award-winning. If you want to understand the big picture of our culture and why we have the unyielding dilemmas we face, and how we can solve them, this book is for you. "
results.name: Book Club Discussion - The World Peace Diet by Dr. Will Tuttle

results.description:
Here's a free exhibition at the Tufts University Art Gallery that has gotten good reviews .  It's Tseng Kwong-Chi: Performing for the Camera 

It looks like it worth seeing as a group.  Please join us if you can.  But, please only RSVP if you come. If your plans change, please update your RSVP.


http://artgallery.tufts.edu/exhibitions/2016/performingForCamera.htm


Tseng Kwong-Chi: Performing for the Camera January 21 – May 22, 2016
Tisch Family Gallery

MEDFORD, MA - The Tufts University Art Gallery at the Shirley and Alex Aidekman Arts Center proudly presents Tseng Kwong Chi: Performing for the Camera, from January 21 through May 22, 2016. This exhibition is the first major museum retrospective of works by Tseng Kwong Chi [masked]), a prolific artist and key documentarian of Manhattan's downtown scene in the 1980s. In combining photography with performance, personal identity with global politics, and satire with farce, Tseng created a compelling body of work whose complexity is belied by its easy humor and grace.


Performing for the Camera features over 80 photo-based works alongside archival materials by the Hong Kong–born artist, who died in 1990 at the age of 39 from AIDS–related complications. In addition to works from the artist's best-known East Meets West and Expeditionary series and nine images of his close friend Keith Haring's drawings in New York city subways, Tseng Kwong Chi: Performing for the Camera presents over 60 examples from less well-known bodies of work.

For his landmark East Meets West series, begun in 1979, Tseng adopted the identity of a visiting Chinese official, wearing a deadpan expression and a “Mao suit.” Describing himself as both an “ambiguous ambassador” and an “inquisitive traveler,” he assumed the role of a dedicated tourist crisscrossing the globe, always an outsider in a foreign land. These strikingly formal yet performance- based images feature the artist posing before popular tourist sites, such as the Brooklyn Bridge, the Eiffel Tower, or Mount Rushmore, and in magnificent natural settings in the Canadian Rockies and Grand Canyon. By embarking on his own version of a Grand Tour, Tseng was determined to find and identify what was quintessentially American. In another guise, he was an eager and reliable witness to his time, documenting not only his friend Keith Haring's subway drawings but also downtown New York's lively art and nightclub scenes of the 1980s.
results.how_to_find_us: We'll meet in the lobby
results.name: Free Exhibit and Discussion at Tufts University Art Gallery

results.description:
Buses replace trains today between Alewife and Harvard Sq.

Art plus M & M = win win! Co-posted to Boston Cultural Nomads.

This is NOT a tour, it is a socializer. If you want to go on a tour, please do so on your own... 

CHECK IN AT 2:30, put your backpacks in the lockers, get your tickets, and Meet & Greet then at 2:45 we're OFF!   
   
For the 10th time, at this popular & incredible gem of a Museum meetup location. We meet just inside the main entrance & head (this time) to the elevators area by the stairs to the 2nd floor. Then we go into the Tobey Gallery right there & pass through to the Fancy Silverware exhibition. We continue on past the masterpieces portraying George Washington and Napoleon, to the painting called Feigned Flight (image below-- the man in the painting who is pursuing her is not in this image which defines it), Ingres' Studies for the Martyrdom, Moreau's Jacob and the Angel (image below), The incredible Call to Arms mini study sculpture by Rodin, Dante Rossetti, & Burne-Jones's works.  And don't forget the room for the great 16th cent. sculptor statuettes by Bernini.
   
NOTE-- hosts will not linger at some of the galleries but PASS RIGHT THROUGH  others because there will be MUCH MORE to see after this.  So GO! stay with the company. This is a meetup enjoy the company; if you want to come earlier to linger at your fav places do that then.  

At 4 PM regroup at the elevators and head back downstairs to the Surrealist Art (follow the hosts) --note the weird sculpture Detroit Queen. Loop through there and get to the Picassos and the last room back towards the entrance including the Bathers by Renoir and other masterpieces --then meet us again back at the open area cafeteria. 

If you do lose us or get tired, look for others in the meetup at the cafeteria back on the first floor, where we gather again and leave AT 4:45 to Felipe's in Harvard Square. That is a 15 minute walk through Harvard Yard.  

HEADS UP the cafeteria closes at 4 PM! But if you sneak in your own beverage from your locker nobody will be checking ...
   
ADMISSION free for Cambridge residents with a drivers license. Otherwise it's $15. Backpacks not allowed. You can store them in lockers across from the admissions area, alternately there is another locker area down one floor from there.

http://lh3.googleusercontent.com/-7he8jlARtuM/VJmDezIHhRI/AAAAAAAEzwg/v9Rn311tEa8/s288/DSC00954.JPG
results.how_to_find_us: Just inside the main entrance at 2:30

results.description:
Come join Joey, a bookseller at Storybook Cove, who will lead a discussion of the  book, "What Alice Forgot" by Liane Moriarty.

Synopsis of book: "Alice Love is twenty-nine, crazy about her husband, and pregnant with her first child.  So imagine Alice's surprise when she comes to on the floor of a gym (She HATES the gym) and is whisked off to the hospital where she discovers the honeymoon is truly over.  She's getting divorced, she has three kids; and she's actually 39 years old.  Alice must reconstruct the events of a lost decade, and find out whether it's possible to reconstruct her life at the same time.  She has to figure out why her sister hardly talks to her, and how is it that she's become one of those skinny moms with really expensive clothes.  Ultimately, Alice must discover whether forgetting is a blessing or a curse. and whether it's possible to start over."
results.name: Joey's Book Club will preread the book "What Alice Forgot" by Liane Moriarity

results.description:
Micro-brewer IndieFerm Brewing & roots-band Delta Generators have joined for a special beer collaboration in celebration of the bands' new album, "Hipshakers and Heartbreakers" release. "Hipshakers Pale Ale"

Here is a chance to see how & where this beer & others are brewed at a true micro-brew operation. We've been looking for an excuse to do this one...

This special release is made using almost entirely local malts & crafted the pale ale recipe with lots of hop aromas. The limited release beer will be available at New World Tavern Saturday night but this will be your exclusive first-time to sample before the premier evening music event.

Specializing in brewing Belgium-inspired & rustic beer styles, our friend Paul, will take us thru the process and highlight the use of locally sourced barley, wheat and rye malts, and what makes local beer so great.

Of course responsible tasting will be a part of it all.

Be sure your updated profile photo is included in your rsvp as a courtesy to fellow members as well as be counted in attending.
results.name: MICRO-BREWERY TASTING, TOUR & SPECIAL LIMITED RELEASE

results.description:
The cast is great, and it's one of Alan Rickman's last films. Note that we're going to the 5 pm screening.

About the film:

In the tense, edge-of-your-seat thriller Eye in the Sky, Helen Mirren stars as Colonel Katherine Powell, a U.K.-based military officer in command of a top secret drone operation to capture terrorists in Kenya. Through remote surveillance and on-the-ground intel, Powell discovers the targets are planning a suicide bombing and the mission escalates from “capture” to “kill.” But as American pilot Steve Watts (Aaron Paul) is about to engage, a nine-year-old girl enters the kill zone, triggering an international dispute reaching the highest levels of U.S. and British government over the moral, political and personal implications of modern warfare. Also starring Alan Rickman, Barkhad Abdi, Jeremy Northam, Iain Glen and Phoebe Fox, Eye in the Sky is directed by Gavin Hood (Tsotsi, Rendition, Ender’s Game).


Afterwards we'll go to an area restaurant for discussion. 

Hope you can make it!

Lisa

results.description:
Hello Friends And Seekers


Better World Meditation will be holding a unique evening activity with a 45 minute workshop led by Herb Pearce, well known author of 5 books on the "Ennegam" (Personality) types, - Enneagram Basics, Enneagram Beyond the Basics, The Caregiver’s  Enneagram, Lessons from the River and Herb’s Tips for Living. The evening will start off with a Calming Meditation by Steven Kriger, founder of Better World Meditation. Our mission is to "Create a better world through spiritual practice" 

*Herb Pearce*, M.Ed. in Counseling,  is a psychotherapist, workshop leader, and personality types trainer in many organizations. He has been teaching the Enneagram to hundreds of audiences and organizations in the last 25 years and uses the Enneagram in his counseling practice with an emphasis on improved relationship dynamics for individuals, couples and families.


Date: Saturday, March 26th from 6:30PM-9:00PM

results.description:
Dear Boston Culture Lovers,

The Berklee Middle Eastern Festival is an annual event that joins artists from the Middle East, the Balkans, and the Mediterranean with students from all over the world.  This event will celebrate the music and culture of Syria.

A highlight of this year’s festival is the hour-long multimedia project Home Within, an impressionistic reflection of the Syrian revolution in which art and music develop in counterpoint to each other. Created and performed by Syrian composer and clarinetist Kinan Azmeh and Syrian-American visual artist Kevork Mourad, Home Within has toured the U.S. and Europe, raising awareness and funds for Syrian refugees.


I strongly recommend that you purchase your tickets in advance. You may purchase your tickets </a> <a href="https://www.berklee.edu/events/home-within-music-syria">berklee.edu/events.  Admission is $8 in advance, $12 day of show .

The concert starts at 7:00 pm, however the meeting time for the group is set for 6:30 pm at the main entrance of venue.  

Please only reserve "YES" if you are definitely attending and plan to meet members of the group.  If you reserve "YES" and have a change of plans, please update the attendance reservation.

I look forward to enjoying this event with the group.

Joana 

***********************************************************************

Additional Information

Directed by festival founder and associate professor Christiane Karam, the event will also feature performances by Syrian oud virtuoso Kenan Adnawi and his ensemble, and Javier Limón, a seven-time Latin Grammy Award-winning flamenco guitarist and artistic director of the Berklee Mediterranean Music Institute. The concert will open with the Berklee Middle Eastern Fusion Ensemble, the Pletenitsa Balkan Choir, and other guests.


https://www.berklee.edu/news/berklee-middle-eastern-festival-music-syria


http://artistecard.com/kenanadnawiofficial


http://kinanazmeh.com/videos/page/2/



Directions and Parking Information 


• Getting here via public transportation (MBTA)Green Line

Get off at Arlington station. Walk north along Arlington Street toward the Charles River. Turn left onto the third street, Marlborough Street. T

Via the Orange Line or Commuter Rail

Get off either train at Back Bay Station. Walk north along Clarendon Street toward the Charles River. Turn right onto the fifth street, Marlborough Street. 

• Parking

Parking is available at the Boston Common Parking Garage (located at Zero Charles St, below the Boston Common Park) on Saturdays all day and on week days after 4 pm for $10.
results.how_to_find_us: at the entrance at 6:30pm

results.description:
The French wine region of Beaujolais has long been considered part of Burgundy, but today it charts its own course. Useful to Know: The region produces almost only red wine with Gamay Noir grapes. Beaujolais wines run the gamut from zippy, juicy-yeasty “Nouveau” style to more serious (but still affordable) Cru vineyard Beaujolais that drinks a lot like red Burgundy, and at this tasting, we will focus on these.

You may need some help from your wine seller, since none of the labels will actually say Cru Beaujolais.  There are only ten areas that produce Cru Beaujolais, and they are:  1. Saint-Amour  2. Juliénas  3. Chénas  4. Moulin-à-Vent  5. Fleurie  6. Chiroubles  7. Morgon  8. Régnié  9. Côte de Brouilly  10. Brouilly... so look for one of those.

This website has great information on each Cru as well as on the region and its wines:  http://winefolly.com/review/beaujolais-wine-region-map/

Please bring a bottle of Cru Beaujolais in a paper wine bag, 4 glasses, and some food to share.
results.name: Cru Beaujolais

REGISTRATION OPTIONS:

$397 WHOLE WEEKEND INTENSIVE: FEARLESS RELATING IN LIFE, LOVE (INCLUDES SAT NIGHT PUJAFEST) AND SEX (SUNDAY)


Fri 7-10pm

Sat 10:30am-5pm

Sat night 7-11pm

Fri 7-10pm

Sat 10:30am-5pm

Sat night 7-11pm

SECURE YOUR TICKET HERE: 

https://www.eventbrite.com/e/fearless-relating-weekend-intensive-with-reid-mihalko-monique-darling-tickets-19758347750

Be sure to secure your spot via eventbrite! (RSVPs on MeetUp do not reflect accurate registration numbers, nor do they secure your spot.) 

I am so excited by this rare East Coast appearance by Cuddle Party creator Reid Mihalko and his fun and exciting co-hostess and international phenom, Monique Darling!

We will begin the evening with one hour devoted to getting everyone on the same page about energy play resonance style......where we will cover many topics that can include.....


Would you like to expand the range of your ENERGETIC sexual experience?Turn YOUR life into an orgasmic playground that doesn’t have to look anything like “sex”…Learn to get in touch with your own energetic field, manipulate it, and turn it into a powerful source of connection and bliss.Discover how and where to touch another to tune into, access, tease and play with their erotic energy, the energy of two people, or the energy of a entire group!Tap into the energy of all 7 major chakra’s by yourself, with a partner, or in a groupDiscover the differences in “taste” between energetic orgasms from chakra to chakraLet me show you our tools, tips and tricks for unlocking your stuck sexual energyAND of course be shown and get to play with Monique's Infamous creation... the "Heart Fuck!" 


Monique has traveled all over the country doing puja's of every type imaginable and would like to give you a taste of ALL of them!


What is a puja? A puja is a ceremony to practice the path of tantra. In the East, puja is a celebration of the Divine, an honoring ceremony for a God or a Goddess, and those somewhere in between ;) In the West, we also celebrate the Divine, the divine in each of us. A puja is a group of people like you, open to celebrating heart felt interactions. During a puja we pair up with partners and practice different exercises that are designed to open our hearts, and deeper connect with ourselves and with others. It is an evening that will nurture your body, heart and spirit.


This will be Boston's first 3way puja! You will have the unique opportunity to do the stations (exercises) in groups of 3. Monique and Reid will sprinkle in tools, tidbits, and tips on how to navigate successful threeways, and we will pull us down into a deep dive to experience every station to its fullest.


You are can come by yourself, with a partner, or with a couple of partners! Singles, couples, triads, pods and more are all welcome! People of all gender identities, sexual orientations, and relationship orientations are invited. :)


This is an excellent safe fully clothed structured space, for you to get to move through the potential awkward moments of interacting in a small group, plus it will just be a fun, connective, humorous evening, wherein we get permission to laugh at ourselves, to not have to "get it right" as you dare to try out something new.


Things to look forward to:

• Loosen the shackles that bind your heart and tongue as you find your divine reflection through each person you interact with. 

• Be witnessed with such clarity and unconditional love, you will emerge transformed. 

• Begin to connect with others in wonder, curiosity, and utter awareness, celebrating the divine presence within us all.

• Enter a wonderland of delights where every touch sensation you can imagine (and even a few beyond your wildest dreams) are laid out for you to explore. 

• Explore both touching and being touched for your own pleasure, taking turns to fully focus on giving and then on receiving touch.

• Practice asking for the exact touch that you are craving in any moment. 

• Hold one another's tears• Communicate with another in total silence

• Be guided on a journey using the most intimate form of touch, our breath. 

• We’ll be introducing an ancient ritual where you will explore each-others bodies, magnifying your connection physically, energetically, and spiritually.

• Then align your chakras through touch, breath, connection, and shared intent.

• Then earth touch, as you ground, and recenter, massage, nurture, hold, BE with one another.

• Followed by fire, as you invigorate, entice, awaken, arouse, "heat" up yourself and your partner

• Cooling down with water touch, fluid, soft, caressing, gentle, swaying, following, gliding o With each element drop even deeper into your embodied bliss state as you learn to touch for YOUR pleasure, as you get to practice asking for the specific types of touch your body is craving/imagining at any moment.


If you come with partner(s), you can do all the negotiated exercises with one another, or you can choose to rotate through the room, where at each station (Exercise) you will have a chance to interact with 2 or more new people. 


GENERAL INFO

* Please eat before you arrive. 

* This is a guided event and maintains strict boundaries which are firmly enforced. 

* Please arrive 6:30-7pm. * Doors will be locked at 7:15 pm so don’t be late! 

* At this point we will begin the opening circle to create a safe and sacred container, so that we are all on the same page. No one will be admitted after the circle begins.


Love Offering: $40 per person (or it is also included in our weekend intensive)


We expect this multi-MeetUp event to sell out, so be sure to secure your spot via eventbrite! (RSVPs on MeetUp do not reflect accurate registration numbers, nor do they secure your spot.) 

Save your spot here : http://bit.ly/1pgnAK9


Pay at the door (if spots still available): $50 per person


Or get it as part of our Fearless weekend in Boston! 

More details here: https://www.facebook.com/events/1649244578697654/


WHAT TO BRING:

* Nesting area - cushions and anything soft and fuzzy to make your own personal nest on the floor (blankets will be provided)

* a blindfold

* a closed water bottle

* sexy finger food such as strawberries, apricots, chocolate, crackers, cheese, grapes, etc.


ABOUT YOUR FACILITATORS:


Sex and relationship expert Reid Mihalko of www.ReidAboutSex.com helps adults create more self-esteem, self-confidence and greater health in their relationships and sex lives using an inspiring mixture of humor and knowledge. Reid’s workshops and college lectures have been attended by close to 40,000 men and women. He has appeared in media such as Oprah’s Our America With Lisa Ling on OWN, the Emmy award-winning talk show Montel, Dr. Phil’s The Doctors on CBS, Bravo’s Miss Advised, Fox News, in Newsweek, Seventeen, GQ, The Washington Post, and in thirteen countries and at least seven languages.


Monique Darling, workshop facilitator extraordinaire has led over 800 workshops in the past 5 years. She is the founder of Juicy Enlightenment an organization dedicated to empowering people who are questioning the assumptions of how their life should be and to offering tools for self expression that create trust, inner knowing and wisdom to enjoy the life they have. Monique has been featured on TLC and The Dr’s as well as various radio shows, podcasts and magazines across the USA. She specializes in helping others reclaim their power and natural sensuality by transmuting fear and repression into courage, self-love and freedom. Her primary purpose is helping folks bring out their vulnerability, energetic embodiment and fearless relating.She guides from a place of understanding and her natural exuberance is infectious! She is available for private sessions, experiential workshops and Cuddle Parties. Learn more about Monique by going to juicyenlightenment.com or track her whereabouts at whereintheworldismoniquedarling.com

Have you played Dodgeball as an adult before? If you haven’t yet, it is ALOT of FUN!!! It's very casual, fun, and good exercise! All levels are welcome! We will be playing on a padded floor, wearing socks and using fairly soft dodgeballs. The arena is air conditioned and is smaller than a typical dodgeball court. There are two individual bathrooms that some people change in. Some people come prepared to play, while others change.

Dodgeball of Boston is located at 1 Broadway in Arlington, MA. There is a parking lot, emphasis on small, and free street parking available on the side streets. Public transportation is available. It's about one mile from Davis Sq Redline T and Alewife T Stations.

Cost is $10. Please make sure to have exact $10 bills - Cash Only, as there will not be much change. Credit Cards will NOT be accepted, so please come prepared. Thanks!

For more information, please visit their website at:
www.dodgeballofboston.com


PS: Ideally it is great to come on time, but if you do arrive late(Asian time), no worries. We will be playing until 9:30pm at least. But you'll just have less playing time, so please arrive on time if you can. See you guys soon!

Saturday, March 26, 2016
7:30pm 10:30pm
The Gallery at Villageworks PRESENTED BY FUGITIVE PRODUCTIONS. Take a red-hot horn—down and dirty. Add liberal amounts of barrelhouse boogie-woogie piano and stinging Fender guitar. Pour over a funky and swinging rhythm section that Blues Review magazine called “the best in the business,” and top it all off with a crazy and charismatic front man with one of the biggest blues voices around. Season with a few years on the road, tearing up juke joints, festivals, and concert halls across the U.S. and Canada and on both sides of the Atlantic. Sound tasty? It's a recipe for music and mayhem, for intensity and irreverence; it's THE LOVE DOGS.

The Dogs combine elements of jump blues, New Orleans R&B and early rock 'n' roll into their own powerhouse sound. “It’s important to us to have fun, and sometimes even we don’t know what we’re gonna do next," says lead vocalist and chief songwriter Eddie "Duato" Scheer. “We have a lot of humor in our music, and we love to surprise each other and make each other laugh.

“We're all lifetime fans of blues, jazz, and R&B, and we have a real reverence for the music. The whole is greater than the sum of its parts.” The band’s lineup consists of Scheer, Alizon Lissance (keyboards, vocals), Myanna (alto/tenor sax, vocals), Glenn Shambroom (guitar, baritone sax), Randy Bramwell (bass, vocals), and Steve Brown (drums, vocals).

Blues Review notes: “If there was a Superbowl for crowd pleasing rhythm & blues, a photo of The Love Dogs would be on every Wheaties box in America.” Scheer sums it up by saying, “If this band doesn’t put a smile on your face, check your pulse because you just might be dead!”

SAVE THE DATE! Tickets will go on sale in February. Sign up for our eblast and you'll be the first to know when tickets are available.
results.name: The Love Dogs at the Gallery at Villageworks in Acton

Emily Noël - soprano & autoharp

George Lykogiannis - accordion

Logistical info here. 

$10-20 - Purchase tickets here.

________________________________________

Developing a varied career as performer, composer/arranger, and scholar, Andrew Arceci performs regularly on the viola da gamba (viol), violone, and double bass throughout North America, Europe, and Asia. In the United Kingdom, he has appeared with the Orchestra of the Age of Enlightenment, Cöthen Baroque, and Oxford Baroque. In the United States, he has collaborated with the Boston Camerata, Handel & Haydn Society, the Arcadia Players, Tempesta di Mare - Philadelphia Baroque Orchestra, Harmonious Blacksmith, The Folger Consort, the Washington Bach Consort, and the Washington National Cathedral; he currently serves as principal bassist with Boston’s L'Académie Baroque Orchestra and Chicago’s Baroque Band. He has given workshops at the University of Oxford (UK), the University of Cambridge (UK), the University of Edinburgh (UK), the Narnia Arts Academy (Narni; Italy), the Taipei National University of the Arts (Taiwan), Burapha University (Thailand), and Bloomsburg University of Pennsylvania (USA). Currently, he directs the Collegium Musicum at Wellesley College, serves on the Winchendon Cultural Council, and works as a freelance artist throughout North America, Europe, and Asia.

George Lernis (drummer, world percussionist) specializes in a number of world percussion instruments such as: Darbuka, Bendir, Daire, Riq, just to name a few. George holds a bachelor’s degree from Berklee College of Music in Jazz Performance and a master’s degree from Longy Conservatory in Modern American Music. Currently George resides in Boston where he regularly performs and teaches music. Over the last few years, George has recorded and collaborated with prominent figures such as: Dave Liebman, Anat Cohen, Antonio Sanchez, Tiger Okoshi, Jerry Leake, Bertram Lehmann, Mehmet Ali Salnikol, and Robert Labaree. After his master’s degree, George released his first album as a bandleader, “Shapes of Nature” featuring the George Lernis Jazz Quartet. George performs regularly around the New England area, New York, as well as touring around the United States and Europe.

Accordionist, George Lykogiannis, works on both accordion and piano. He has performed with Make Music New York's accordion "Mass Appeal", and has played shows with artists throughout the United States. As a pianist, Mr. Lykogiannis performed with the IU Concert Orchestra under the baton of David Effron in February of 2011 as winner of Indiana University’s “Totentanz” competition (Bloomington, IN). Mr. Lykogiannis made his orchestral debut with the Orchestra Sinfonica del Festival di Chioggia (Veneto, Italy) in 2000, and appeared in concert with them again in 2007 and 2009. In the fall of 2003, he made his United States orchestral debut with the Plainfield Symphony Orchestra (NJ). Mr. Lykogiannis attended Rowan University (Glassboro, NJ) where he studied under Raffi Besalyan, and graduated Summa Cum Laude in May of 2008 with a Bachelor Degree in Music Performance. In May of 2012, he received a Master of Music degree from Indiana University’s Jacobs School of Music, having studied under Professor Emile Naoumoff. Mr. Lykogiannis is currently pursuing a Doctorate of Musical Arts (DMA) in piano at Rutgers University.

Soprano Emily Noël has appeared as a soloist with The Gabrieli Consort, The Folger Consort, The Washington Bach Consort, 21stCentury Consort, Orchestra of the 17th Century, Bach Sinfonia, and Indiana University New Music Ensemble; and was featured as the soprano soloist in CPE Bach’s Magnificat at the 2014 American Bach Society Annual Meeting. In recent seasons, she has sung a wide range of operatic roles, notably Gilda in Verdi’s Rigoletto with Ente Concerti Città di Iglesias (Sardinia, Italy); Nora in Vaughn Williams’ Riders to the Sea at the Amsterdam Grachtenfestival (Netherlands); The Witch in Purcell’s The Witch of Endor at the Washington National Cathedral; and Debora in selections from Guglielmi’s Debora e Sisara with Modern Musick at the Italian Embassy as part of the 2013 Anno Della Cultura Italiana. Ms. Noël earned her Master of Music in voice from Peabody Conservatory and her Bachelor of Music from the University of Maryland; currently she serves as an Assistant Professor of Music at The Community College of Rhode Island.

Touring extensively as a solo, chamber, and orchestral player throughout Europe, Asia, and North America, violinist Asako Takeuchihas performed with ensembles such as the Wallfisch Band (UK), Collegium Musicum Den Haag (Netherlands), Den Haag Piano Quintet (Netherlands), The Bach Choir & Orchestra of the Netherlands, Arion Baroque Orchestra (Canada), and Handel & Haydn Society (USA). She has performed at numerous festivals, including Festival Oude Muziek Utrecht (Netherlands), Deutsches Mozartfest and Innsbruck Festival (Germany), Festival de Música Antigua de Barcelona (Spain), MUPA International Arts Festival (Thailand), Abbaye aux Dames (France), and Aston Magna Music Festival (USA). Discography includes recordings with The Wallfisch Band (soloist), Arion Baroque Orchestra, and The Bach Choir & Orchestra of the Netherlands. She has given workshops at Burapha University (Thailand), and holds degrees from the Royal Conservatory in the Hague (Netherlands), University of Southern California, and Berklee College of Music.

________________________________________

"Soprano Emily Noël gave sparkling performances of polished Claudio Monteverdi songs, as well as more homespun English ballads in a sort of entr’acte of groundling music." Washington Post

"In addition to the superb instrumentalists (a couple of bagpipes made a delicious appearance along the way), Peabody-trained soprano Emily Noël offered deftly sculpted singing. A classy enterprise all the way." Baltimore Sun

“The opening Grave, with subtle nuances in Andrew Arceci’s viola da gamba and overall intricate textures, conveyed the quiet and poised joy of daily thanksgiving." THE BOSTON MUSICAL INTELLIGENCER

"Andrew Arceci was heroic in the wide-ranging solo part..." SEEN AND HEARD INTERNATIONAL

"Andrew Arceci brought a lovely tone to the line and matched the dramatic impulses that propelled the superb ensemble playing." THE NEW YORK TIMES

“...his modernistic approach to drumming, Lernis expands upon the restrictive role of timekeeper, playing a naturally flowing amalgamation of shifting rhythms that distinguishes his work from more typical mainstream jazz while maintaining an appealing sound.” Drumhead Magazine.
results.how_to_find_us: Ask for Jeff Boudreau at the will-call table.

results.description:
The next big thing in music from these groundbreakers...!

Special album release tour appearance, entitled "Hipshakers and Heartbreakers" by our very good friends, Delta Generators, with a sound & style all their own.

Over the last few years, the great Delta Generators have shared the stage with Robert Cray, Barrence Whitfield, Dirty Dozen Brass Band, Three Dog Night, James Cotton, Jimmie Vaughn, The Fabulous Thunderbirds, Johnny Winter, Walter Trout, Papa Chubby, Bonerama, Michael Burkes, John Lee Hooker, and Sonny Landreth among many others...

The Cavern at New World Tavern is a great venue & we'll try to grab the usual spot up front, directly adjacent to the band (aka our "mosh pit").

The new CD will be available as well as their others. We'll get the band over to sign your very own take-home copy.

This will be a terrific evening. First timers especially welcome.

Be sure your updated profile photo is included in rsvp, so we can locate & welcome you! This is a courtesy to yourself & fellow members as well as required to be counted in attendance.

no cover

results.description:
Spring is here! What better way to celebrate warm weather, flowers blooming,mane sunshine than in the back of a dive bar with Boston A-List's Best Night of Comedy, THE MENDOZA LINE!

This and every Saturday night live from the back room of the The Dugout Cafe (722 Comm Ave), John Baglio, Julia Claire, and Zach "Zack" Armentrout bring you a different lineup stacked with the biggest, baddest, and bestiest comedians from Boston and beyond. And guess what? Its only FIVE DOLLARS! With drink specials as far as the eye can see and free popcorn, this intimate atmosphere is the perfect place to take in some meaningful and quality laughs!

Here's the link to buy your tickets now to guarantee a seat as room is limited. Our shows have frequently sold out, and we'd hate to break your little heart and turn you away: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/the-mendoza-line-bostons-best-weekly-comedy-showcase-tickets-15228587114

This week's INCREDIBLE show features the comedic talents of:

Thom Crowley (Boston Comedy Festival, TedX)

Erin Spencer (ImprovBoston)

Shaun Bedgood (Comedy Central's UpNext)

Emily Ruskowski (opened for Maria Bamford and Arsenio Hall)

SPECIAL GUEST HOST RICK CANAVAN (The Comedy Studio)

AND MORE! COME TO THIS AND FIND OUT WHAT IT MEANS TO LIVE FOREVER!
results.name: The Mendoza Line! $5 Comedy Showcase!

venue.name: ROXBURY CENTER FOR ARTS at HIBERNIAN HALL

results.description:
DONT MISS 

                                            4G's & FRIENDS

                                MONUMENTAL 8TH ANNUAL

           MAGNIFICENT MARCH 2016 CROWNING EVENT 

                                 SEMI FORMAL ATTIRE

                                         COVER: $20pp

           For suggested hotels visit  CLASSES & EVENT page @                                          www.stepinthebean.org

MAGNIFICENT MARCH is not just an event, 
it's a TRADITION. 

MAGNIFICENT MARCH is a celebration of the presence of the culture and dance of Chicago Style Steppin in Boston. "STEPPIN IN THE BEAN." On the first Saturday of Spring in March 2009, at the Roxbury Center For Arts / Hibernian Hall, this annual celebration was launched by Steppin In The Bean Foundation Inc. to chronicle it's first year of teaching and promoting the culture and dance of 
Chicago Style Steppin. 
This weekend long celebration of True Chicago Style Steppinconsisted of two days of workshops Instructed by visitingInstructors Kevin Richards who was first to introduce the culture and dance to Boston, and the illustrious Andre Blackwell well known as R.Kelly's choreographer, and theSteppers' Set of the year on the first Saturday Night of Spring.The first Saturday of Spring was subsequently declared by formal proclamation of the Boston City Counsel;   "STEPPIN IN THE BEAN DAY IN THE CITY OF BOSTON."
For the 6th Annual MAGNIFICENT MARCH MAIN EVENT a Mastermind Collaborative consisting of 4 gentlemen was formed to co-sponsor that years celebration. These gentlemen areChris Chaney ("Uncle Chris") of Chicago who joined the Steppin In The Bean Leadership Team when he moved to Boston, MixMaster Rudy Dottin (Boston's 1st Steppin DJ) who has been the traditional MAGNIFICENT MARCH DJ from it's inception, James Brown (Happy Feet) a former prodIgy student of Steppin The Bean who received the first ever Steppin In The Bean Achievement Award for his evolution into Founding CEO and Lead Instructor of the smooth RED VELVET STEPPERS, and A.W. Taqwa (Step Bro. Taqwa) the Founding CEO and Lead Instructor of STEPPIN IN THE BEAN FOUNDATION INC. 

These are the 4G's, the Executive Producers of The 8th Annual MAGNIFICENT MARCH 2016 KINGS & QUEENS BALL, & you the co-sponsors, vendors, contributors, space providers, workshop facilitators, security team, technical staff, and every guest in attendance, are the FRIENDS.
The 4G's thank you for making this symbolic monumental 8th year truly the  CROWNING EVENT! 
Special thanks to Madison Park Development Corporation for nine years of hospitality at HIBERNIAN HALL.    
We bid you all  HAPPY STEPPIN IN THE BEAN DAY             

as together we

EMBRACE THE CULTURE, EMBRACE THE DANCE!
results.name: 4G's & FRIENDS: 8th Annual MAGNIFICENT MARCH 2016 CROWNING EVENT

venue.name: The New England Center for Homeless Veterans

results.description:
I volunteer a couple of times a month serving lunch at the shelter. Great group of men and women who have served our country and have come back needing a little help. The Center, which was started by a Veteran, provides housing, health care, social services, food, as well as a multitude of other services for our returning heroes. They have volunteer groups come in on weekends and do breakfast service. We don't provide the food, just smiles and friendly faces. The serving starts at 7:15am and we would be done by around 9.  We have gone as a group several times and hope to keep this up monthly, there's a limit to 6 servers each time. It's really a wonderful time. Some of the ladies asked about baking/bringing something. I also spoke with the head of the kitchen....just avoid things with nuts because of allergies. Hope to see you all then! We can carpool, it's near the Orange line and if you drive in you can park right in front. Also remember a hat, you need to have your head/hair covered to serve.

 My telephone number if you have any questions or have a last minute change to status is[masked]

2 things:
1. Since this is a popular event, I'd like to ask that you only sign up only if you are able to get up early on a Sunday.  There will be several Sundays throughout the year I'll actually take myself off as well so that opens up one spot. On the days I cook, I'll also open it up to have 7 servers so that more can come.
2. To prevent the # of no shows we've had, I'm going to just let everyone know that if you know show, I will remove you from future volunteer opportunities with the Center. I've hated the times when due to no shows, the Vets have had to step in to help, especially because there are often individuals that were on the wait list and didn't have the opportunity to show. If you cannot attend, please RSVP no ahead of time, or at the very least, just call or text me if you aren't well the morning of the shift, just so I know and can get them to provide help when I get there. My telephone # is[masked]-1526. Those letting me know that they can't make a day ahead of time won't be considered a no show.

Thank you for your ongoing support. I appreciate it and I know that the Veterans do as well.
results.name: Volunteer and serve breakfast at the New England Center for Homeless Veterans

results.description:
This is a 5 mile loop around Hickory Hills Forest and Lunenburg conservation land. It takes approx 2 hours.   It is a nice hike mostly on Cart paths with rolling hills mixed in.. We will meet at 156 S. Row Road, in Lunenburg. Walk over to the trail head and make our way around the forest. Wear sturdy shoes or boots, sneakers are not recommended.  We do encounter streams, wet leaves and rocks, from time to time,. We will not leave anyone behind.  Socially behaved dogs are welcome, please bring your own doggie bags. 

 
Directions.
From the center of Lunenburg
Rte 2A East Approx 3/4 mile turn left onto Townsend Harbor Road.
Travel approx 1/2 mile on Townsend Harbor Road to the stop sign. Turn left at the stop sign to continue on Townsend Harbor Road.
Travel approx another 1/2 mile at the fork stay left onto South Row Road. Follow South Row Road for approx 1/2 mile.
My house is on the right.
Uturn Driveway, Brown house. Pull right into the driveway.

We meet for 9:00 and try to take off promptly.  

IF YOUR PLANS CHANGE, PLEASE CHANGE YOUR RSVP!

Thank you, I look forward to another successful hike.
results.name: Trail Hiking, Rolling terrrain

results.description:
Croiss-training combines biking and bakeries.  The route goes from Spy pond, heads west to Shade St in Lexington, out past Hanscom to Concord (possible coffee & pastry stop) then Chelmsford, Tyngsboro, around Long Pond then into Lowell for lunch at mile 45.  Then down to Billerica via a different Long Pond,  pick up the minuteman in Bedford and cruise home to Spy Bond.   Total distance just under 70 miles. 

This is a sociable ride -- nobody will be left behind.   Overall pace will be an hour for each 10 miles, including stops, with a moving average of about 12-13 mph.

If coming by T, take the minuteman from Alewife up to Spy Pond - it's about 10  minutes.  It's more scenic to wait for people by the pond than by the station!

For some reason, the meetup user interface keeps messing with my start point.   The real start point is spy pond circle at the end of Linwood Ave, not the 1165R Mass Ave that the software is putting there with no help from me.   

Any road bike should be fine - racing or hybrid.

Route cue sheet is 

http://www.strava.com/routes/3514086


If the group is feeling extra energetic, we might stretch it up to Nashua for 80 miles, but let's see how everybody is feeling, especially after we climb out of Belmont on Concard Ave!

http://www.strava.com/routes/4467915

Scene from Lowell in October...

Route map.
results.how_to_find_us: At the little circle off the minuteman trail at the south end of spy pond - IGNORE the auto-generated reference to 1165R provided by the meetup website!
results.name: Croiss-training Circuit To NH

results.description:
Poses begin the first Sunday of the month unless otherwise noted.

Meet to paint the model for a five week pose- Members (those paying the $25 monthly membership fee) may reserve a spot for $55, non-members for $70.    Three hours each Sunday morning, 9:30-12:30.  You can come individual days by paying $15 (members) or $25 (non-members) for a single drop-in, but please consider paying for the full amount and committing to come!  It will help us to keep these long sessions going, and even if you pay for the whole session and don't come to all of them (often happens), you're getting a pretty square deal.  If you would like to pay online please do so at


http://damonlehrer.com/damonlehrer.com/payment.html 

PLEASE TRY TO BE ON TIME-  folks who come later than 10:00 am will be admitted ONLY at the convenience of the host (who is busy painting). PLEASE NOTE THE PRICES BELOW- They are deliberately a bit higher than for drawing sessions as we keep the studio less crowded for painting, and it's more work to put together a four week pose.  

----- IF THE CAPACITY REACHES 12, whether or not that number shows up on the RSVP list, we may have to close the session to further drop-ins to preserve breathing space for those who reserved ahead. ------

 Please consider that for $75 or $90 (non-member) you can reserve ahead for the whole month, which helps us stay open for business.  If you want to drop in, you can RSVP and pay online- simply change the amount of the payment at the payment stage to reflect the drop-in rate above.
results.how_to_find_us: corner of Vernon and Central streets

results.description:
Meet to paint the model for a five week pose- Members (those paying the $25 monthly membership fee) may reserve a spot for $75, non-members for $90.    Three hours each Sunday morning, 9:30-12:30.  You can come individual days by paying $15 (members) or $25 (non-members) for a single drop-in, but please consider paying for the full amount and committing to come!  It will help us to keep these long sessions going, and even if you pay for the whole session and don't come to all of them (often happens), you're getting a pretty square deal.  If you would like to pay online please do so at


http://damonlehrer.com/damonlehrer.com/payment.html 

PLEASE TRY TO BE ON TIME-  folks who come later than 10:00 am will be admitted ONLY at the convenience of the host (who is busy painting). PLEASE NOTE THE PRICES BELOW- They are deliberately a bit higher than for drawing sessions as we keep the studio less crowded for painting, and it's more work to put together a four week pose.  

----- IF THE CAPACITY REACHES 12, whether or not that number shows up on the RSVP list, we may have to close the session to further drop-ins to preserve breathing space for those who reserved ahead. ------

 Please consider that for $75 or $90 (non-member) you can reserve ahead for the whole month, which helps us stay open for business.  If you want to drop in, you can RSVP and pay online- simply change the amount of the payment at the payment stage to reflect the drop-in rate above.

results.description:
Charles Derber, Professor of Sociology at Boston College

Professor Derber is a leading social critic, who has written eight widely acclaimed books. The most recent is "People Before Profit: The New Globalization In An Age of Terror, Big Money, and Economic Crisis". Since the publication of Corporation Nation (2000) and the 1999 Seattle protests, Derber has become a prominent national commentator on corporate social responsibility and US foreign policy as well as globalization and its discontents. Interestingly, Trump and Sanders seem to be attracting the same white working class voters.

In this talk, Professor Derber will look at the structural, cultural and ideological crosscurrrents shaping the election, including the shift of the GOP toward neo-Fascism, the spectacular rise of a socialist Democratic candidate, and the ways in which right and left populism are resonating to voters, especially white working class folks.
results.name: The 2016 Election: Fascism, Socialism and the Working Class Voter

results.description:
Join us on court this Sunday at 11 a.m. for the start of this spring season's Beginner Level Group Tennis Clinics conducted by highly experience tennis professionals.


This weekly (every Sunday) series of group clinics is a 6-session, 9 hour (each session runs 90 minutes) series of clinics designed for beginner level tennis players.

The fundamentals of tennis will be covered throughout the series in a format that will utilize precise tennis drills and clear description of fundamentally correct tennis technique to reinforce these tennis essentials with each participating player.

Each 90-minute session in the series will include: warm-up exercises; dynamic stretching; cardio drills; skill-building tennis drills; description and demonstration of fundamentally sound tennis strokes.

Each participant will get to hit many balls during drills under the watchful eye of the supervising tennis pro.

We have priced this series of clinics at the handsomely discounted, cost-friendly rate of just $135. That averages a very low $15/hr/player.

Learn the game of tennis or improve your beginner level strokes. In these clinics, you'll do just that and, at the same time, increase your enjoyment of tennis.

Make this the year you take your tennis game to the next level!

results.description:
As Spring rolls back in, so does Project Freeruns Parkour 101 City Clinics. 

These clinics are designed to introduce those who are beginners or novices at movement to Parkour, The Art of Movement. The classes run in 6 week series to focus each week on a new skill set and area of Parkour Training. 

This first session on March 27 is a trial class to introduce where and how the program will run, and to serve as a basis to enroll for our Spring 1 Series (6 Weeks)

The cost of March 27 is free, and going forward the 6 week series is $60 due before first class. 

FAQs

------

What is Parkour?

Parkour is a training discipline using movement that developed from military obstacle course training. Practitioners aim to get from one point to another in a complex environment, without assistive equipment and in the fastest and most efficient way possible.

Parkour includes running, climbing, swinging, vaulting, jumping, rolling, quadrupedal movement, and other movements as deemed most suitable for the situation. Parkour's development from military training gives it some aspects of a non-combative martial art.

What if I've never done anything like Parkour before? 

This class, Parkour 101, is a introductory level class. We will be focusing more on learning how to move our body, understand our limits and get a solid understanding of how to train safe rather than jumping straight into super-high level flips and jumps. 

What if I'm a gymnast/marine/stuntman/etc? I don't want to be bored.

Our program prides itself on scaling classes to each and every student. With something like Parkour there are many levels and progressions to each movement. It's very common to in the same class have one student working on perfecting their roll, and on the other side of the room have another student practicing very high-level acrobatics. They both come from the same foundation, but are scaled to each practitioners skill level. 

What do I need to bring/prepare?

The great thing about Parkour is its accessibility. You really only need a good pair of shoes. We recommend a shoe that is made for urban running (no aggressive treads, a smoother sole lightweight). Think hiking boots, crocs, skate shoes are all no-nos. 

Other than that, dress appropriately for activity. Shorts, sweats, t-shirts are all good here. Jeans are normally not the best choice. 

We highly recommend bringing water, snacks and a form of transportation (bike, longboard, potentially train fare)

We will be charging a $5 per class fee to start here, and for the 1 hour 15 minute class we think this isn't too ridiculous. We accept cash or card day of. 

Anything else?

These jams will be run outdoors, and with existing architecture. While we won't be getting into anything crazy, injuries are to be expected. Scrapes happen. We will have first aid available, but make sure you are thinking clearly and in your limits before training! 

I am available to answer all questions, but I hope to see a whole bunch of you out in a few weeks!! 

Be sure to check us out on:

https://www.facebook.com/ParkourAndTricking

https://instagram.com/projectfreerun 

http://www.projectfreerun.com/

results.description:
Come and join us for open board gaming at Excelsior!  They have a large gaming area to seat approximately 50 gamers in addition to a growing board game library that patrons may take right off the library shelf and play at-will.  They have also dedicated their Sunday schedule for just this open board gaming event, so us board gamers will have the pick of the tables during the entirety of the event which happens to run the entire time the shop is open on Sundays.

Attendees are welcome to bring in their own games or use games from the library.  Bobby will also run game demos during the event in case you want to learn a new game or simply try before you buy.

In case you are interested in purchasing the game from the demo session, Excelsior will offer 10% off the price of purchasing a new copy of that game that day on top of the 10% discount they are offer to all MBG members (for a total discount of 20% off).  If for some reason they are out of stock of the demo game and must special order it for you that day, they will order it for you and allow you to take an additional 10% special order discount on top of the previous two discounts for a total discount of 30% off!

Want to special order something that is not the demo game?  Add the base TGA 10% discount and the 10% special order discount together for a total of 20% off any special orders.

Nourishment:  The shop carries various snacks and non-alcoholic beverages if you need something to snack or sip on while you game.  For more substantial food, there are many eateries located within walking distance from the shop on Main Street.

Parking:  Excelsior has an agreement in place with the Jiffy Lube at 3 Powder Mill Road.  Attendees may park in the lot behind the Jiffy Lube building.  From there, it is a short walk across Powder Mill Road to the Excelsior's door on the corner of Powder Mill and Waltham Street, which is the 4-way intersection closest to Jiffy Lube.
results.how_to_find_us: On the corner of Waltham Street and Powder Mill Road, park behind the Jiffy Lube

results.description:
This Sunday is the Humanist Hub's 3rd annual Spring Celebration: a way for atheists, agnostics and allies to have a kind of inspirational celebration many of us positively associate with religious holidays of springtime - without religious content (and without being anti-religious either). Mary Johnson, who made this one of the Hub's most loved programs its first two years, returns with passion for this occasion that comes from her 20 years as a nun under Mother Teresa and her recent years as a humanist and atheist leader and prizewinning author.

This year's celebration will reflect the particular unpredictability of this year's weather--and of our lives. Change and uncertainty can be opportunities for growth, learning, and celebration. Join us for an afternoon of mindful reflection and communal appreciation of the new season. It will once again feature great poetry, will be family/kid-friendly, and this time we'll feature the music of beloved local artist Antje Duvekot.

Mary Johnson's prize-winning memoir, An Unquenchable Thirst, tells the story of her twenty years as a nun with Mother Teresa. Now a Humanist celebrant and activist, Mary believes in the power of truth as service. She was voted New Hampshire's top wedding officiant in 2015 and finds great meaning in creating and celebrating personalized weddings and funerals.

This essay on Mary's journey from nun to humanist, and on (re)envisioning a secular spirituality at times of the year that are meaningful in Christian culture, was published in an Easter edition of the New York Times magazine a few years ago: http://www.nytimes.com/2013/03/31/magazine/a-brief-resurrection.html?ref=lives&_r=1. 

For more of Mary's story, see http://www.maryjohnson.co/bio/
results.name: Mary Johnson: Spring: Celebrating Grounded Groundlessness

group.name: The Humanist Hub in Harvard Square

results.description:
We will be meeting at Club Cafe Back Bay.

Instead of the 1 book/month selection. I thought maybe we will try genres and themes.  As usual, the drunk part is optional.

For our March bookclub, I selected "Politics of Fantastical Kingdoms". If you found a book that you love, please leave comment or bring it to the bookclub to surprise us.

The Winner's Curse (The Winner's Trilogy #1) by Marie Rutkoski

Shadow and Bone (The Grisha #1) by Leigh Bardugo

Snow Like Ashes (Snow Like Ashes #1) by Sara Raasch

The Queen of the Tearling by Erika Johansen

The Young Elites by Marie Lu

Red Queen by Victoria Aveyard

An Ember in the Ashes (An Ember in the Ashes #1)

And other books to consider

The Orphan Queen (The Orphan Queen #1) by Jodi Meadows
Truthwitch (The Witchlands #1) by Susan Dennard
Reign of Shadows (Reign of Shadows #1) by Sophie Jordan
The Jewel (The Lone City #1) by Amy Ewing
The False Prince (The Ascendance Trilogy #1) by Jennifer A. Nielsen


As a general’s daughter in a vast empire that revels in war and enslaves those it conquers, seventeen-year-old Kestrel has two choices: she can join the military or get married. But Kestrel has other intentions.
One day, she is startled to find a kindred spirit in a young slave up for auction. Arin’s eyes seem to defy everything and everyone. Following her instinct, Kestrel buys him—with unexpected consequences. It’s not long before she has to hide her growing love for Arin.
But he, too, has a secret, and Kestrel quickly learns that the price she paid for a fellow human is much higher than she ever could have imagined.
Set in a richly imagined new world, The Winner’s Curse by Marie Rutkoski is a story of deadly games where everything is at stake, and the gamble is whether you will keep your head or lose your heart

Shadow and Bone (The Grisha #1) by Leigh Bardugo

Surrounded by enemies, the once-great nation of Ravka has been torn in two by the Shadow Fold, a swath of near impenetrable darkness crawling with monsters who feast on human flesh. Now its fate may rest on the shoulders of one lonely refugee.

Alina Starkov has never been good at anything. But when her regiment is attacked on the Fold and her best friend is brutally injured, Alina reveals a dormant power that saves his life—a power that could be the key to setting her war-ravaged country free. Wrenched from everything she knows, Alina is whisked away to the royal court to be trained as a member of the Grisha, the magical elite led by the mysterious Darkling.

Yet nothing in this lavish world is what it seems. With darkness looming and an entire kingdom depending on her untamed power, Alina will have to confront the secrets of the Grisha . . . and the secrets of her heart.

Snow Like Ashes (Snow Like Ashes #1) by Sara Raasch

A heartbroken girl. A fierce warrior. A hero in the making.

Sixteen years ago the Kingdom of Winter was conquered and its citizens enslaved, leaving them without magic or a monarch. Now, the Winterians’ only hope for freedom is the eight survivors who managed to escape, and who have been waiting for the opportunity to steal back Winter’s magic and rebuild the kingdom ever since.

Orphaned as an infant during Winter’s defeat, Meira has lived her whole life as a refugee, raised by the Winterians’ general, Sir. Training to be a warrior—and desperately in love with her best friend, and future king, Mather — she would do anything to help her kingdom rise to power again.

So when scouts discover the location of the ancient locket that can restore Winter’s magic, Meira decides to go after it herself. Finally, she’s scaling towers, fighting enemy soldiers, and serving her kingdom just as she’s always dreamed she would. But the mission doesn’t go as planned, and Meira soon finds herself thrust into a world of evil magic and dangerous politics – and ultimately comes to realize that her destiny is not, never has been, her own.

The Queen of the Tearling by Erika Johansen


A young woman.
A kingdom.
An evil enemy.
A birthright foretold . . .

With the arrival of her nineteenth birthday, Princess Kelsea Raleigh Glynn is ascending to her rightful place as the new Queen of the Tearling. Surrounded by enemies, including an evil sorceress possessed of dark magic, the young ruler stands little chance of success. But Kelsea possesses fearsome weapons of her own, including the Tear sapphire, a jewel of immense power and magic. As an epic war draws near, Kelsea's quest to save her kingdom and meet her destiny begins—a wondrous journey of self-discovery and a trial by fire that will make her a legend...if she can survive.

The Young Elites by Marie Lu


Adelina Amouteru is a survivor of the blood fever. A decade ago, the deadly illness swept through her nation. Most of the infected perished, while many of the children who survived were left with strange markings. Adelina’s black hair turned silver, her lashes went pale, and now she has only a jagged scar where her left eye once was. Her cruel father believes she is a malfetto, an abomination, ruining their family’s good name and standing in the way of their fortune. But some of the fever’s survivors are rumored to possess more than just scars—they are believed to have mysterious and powerful gifts, and though their identities remain secret, they have come to be called the Young Elites.

Teren Santoro works for the king. As Leader of the Inquisition Axis, it is his job to seek out the Young Elites, to destroy them before they destroy the nation. He believes the Young Elites to be dangerous and vengeful, but it’s Teren who may possess the darkest secret of all.

Enzo Valenciano is a member of the Dagger Society. This secret sect of Young Elites seeks out others like them before the Inquisition Axis can. But when the Daggers find Adelina, they discover someone with powers like they’ve never seen.

Adelina wants to believe Enzo is on her side, and that Teren is the true enemy. But the lives of these three will collide in unexpected ways, as each fights a very different and personal battle. But of one thing they are all certain: Adelina has abilities that shouldn’t belong in this world. A vengeful blackness in her heart. And a desire to destroy all who dare to cross her.

It is my turn to use. My turn to hurt.

Red Queen by Victoria Aveyard

Graceling meets The Selection in debut novelist Victoria Aveyard's sweeping tale of seventeen-year-old Mare, a common girl whose once-latent magical power draws her into the dangerous intrigue of the king's palace. Will her power save her or condemn her?

Mare Barrow's world is divided by blood—those with common, Red blood serve the Silver- blooded elite, who are gifted with superhuman abilities. Mare is a Red, scraping by as a thief in a poor, rural village, until a twist of fate throws her in front of the Silver court. Before the king, princes, and all the nobles, she discovers she has an ability of her own.

To cover up this impossibility, the king forces her to play the role of a lost Silver princess and betroths her to one of his own sons. As Mare is drawn further into the Silver world, she risks everything and uses her new position to help the Scarlet Guard—a growing Red rebellion—even as her heart tugs her in an impossible direction. One wrong move can lead to her death, but in the dangerous game she plays, the only certainty is betrayal.

An Ember in the Ashes (An Ember in the Ashes #1)


Laia is a slave. Elias is a soldier. Neither is free.

Under the Martial Empire, defiance is met with death. Those who do not vow their blood and bodies to the Emperor risk the execution of their loved ones and the destruction of all they hold dear.

It is in this brutal world, inspired by ancient Rome, that Laia lives with her grandparents and older brother. The family ekes out an existence in the Empire’s impoverished backstreets. They do not challenge the Empire. They’ve seen what happens to those who do.

But when Laia’s brother is arrested for treason, Laia is forced to make a decision. In exchange for help from rebels who promise to rescue her brother, she will risk her life to spy for them from within the Empire’s greatest military academy.

There, Laia meets Elias, the school’s finest soldier—and secretly, its most unwilling. Elias wants only to be free of the tyranny he’s being trained to enforce. He and Laia will soon realize that their destinies are intertwined—and that their choices will change the fate of the Empire itself.

results.description:
A photographer who wants to see, and make fine images, must recognize the value of the familiar. Freeman Patterson

If you are not busy hunting for Easter Eggs this Sunday, join us for a unique treasure hunt as we search for visual gems hidden in plain sight. Fort Point Channel also know as the Seaport District is an area rich with photo opportunities. I will provide maps if you are not familiar with the area. Come explore and learn the art of seeing.

We can all recognize the beauty of a flower or a sunset. But can you see the beauty of  a rusty hinge, a crumbling wall or graffiti? Come discover the urban landscape beauty and how to make the ordinary extraordinary through your photography.


An abstract photo is often viewed with the response, wow that's beautiful, but what is it? Abstract photos delight us even if we are not sure why. They are created in the moment you feel a shift and see something in a fresh way. I have developed some simple practices to help you feel that shift and see your world with fresh eyes. I will share 3 of these with you during the program this Sunday.

Learning to see creatively means slowing down to notice simple details right in front of you the have the potential to make a great photo. The things other people walk right by will suddenly jump out at you begging for your attention.

First,we will meet in front of South Station. I will introduce you to some simple step by step practices for creative seeing so you can find beauty in the most unexpected places. I will show you some inspiring example photos to help get you started. I will help challenge your assumptions about what makes an interesting photo by giving you specific structured assignments.  I design these assignments very carefully to build your skills.

You will have a chance to try these out right away with my guidance in the Fort Point Channel area.  You will receive individual coaching and critique while we are in the field shooting. This way you can be confident that you will be able to repeat the process next time you are out on a shoot.

We will work with color, texture, pattern, and light to make our photos come to life. As always, this is a non technical jargon zone. It is all about the creative act of seeing and capturing the moments of life with a fresh eye.

This workshop is for you if:

• You want to join a group of like minded people and learn some new photography skills. 

• You are interested in abstract photography but not sure what makes a "good" photo.

• You are familiar with composition "rule of thirds" but not sure how to apply it to abstract subjects.


• You are attracted to the visual elements of color, pattern and texture.

Any camera is fine for this shoot. You can even use your iPhone if you like. This is a fun, fast paced workshop. So if you would like to meet other people who love photography and are curious about how to take better photos, I hope you will join us. This is a totally different way to spend Easter Sunday! Now you do have plans.

The tuition for the workshop is $45.00 and included handouts, one on one instruction as needed. If you need some extra help with camera settings we can do that too. 

We are going to have a great time! You have joined the group, now join the fun. 

RSVP right away to hold your space. I look forward to seeing you Sunday 

Suzanne

http://itunes.apple.com/us/book/flow-tography-better-photos/id499049037?mt=11&uo=4

results.description:
Give yourself the gift of relaxation and rejuvenation with a wonderful 90 minute gentle yoga and meditation class.

True relaxation is experienced by the body and mind when little or no energy is consumed. It is Nature's way of recharging. Since every action, conscious or unconscious, uses stored energy, relaxation is necessary for good health and peace of mind. Without proper relaxation the body and mind become overworked and inefficient.

When the mind is constantly bombarded by stimuli, it becomes overloaded and exhausted. We may be unaware that we are doing it, but by thinking and worrying we are using up tremendous amounts of energy. The tension put on the mind by worries can use more energy than physical work.

Yoga retrains the body to relax and can calm the mind which leads to inner peace.

This class is for beginners and experienced yogi's.  Chairs are available for those who may need to sit during this class.  Please bring your own yoga mat, water and a blanket or pillow for meditation.

results.description:
This month is particularly filled with cosmic downpours of light, love and higher consciousness. Our personal awakening process has never been this supported. Join us this Sunday for Judy's guided journey to the top of Calvary, where you will experience a felt sense of your own resurrection phase.

This is an ongoing weekly (donation only) class for anyone, offering experiential practice in meditation, along with an opportunity to be among others interested in deepening spiritual practices.  The class provides you with a felt sense of your own divinity; your Higher Self. The meditation, based on Kriya practices,  is partly guided, partly silent. In the guided part we open up to the flow of golden light and energy that is always pouring down to our body/mind/heart and being. Accessing that flow and inviting it to fill us brings a profound level of openness, while washing away limiting thoughts, feelings and beliefs.   
   This higher vibration of unconditional love serves to open our consciousness to new levels of peace, joy and awakening. Bringing the flow of light into the body/mind/heart means we more consciously embody our Light Being, so we are more present, happy, forgiving, peaceful and joyful while in the world.
   After the guided portion we spend time in peaceful silence.  Whether you are an experienced meditator or a beginner, you will love the sweetness and powerful energies of this group. At the end of the class we make time for questions or sharing.  Group meditation is powerful, and it's refreshing to be among fellow travelers!
   Judy also teaches the Sound and Light meditation; a way for you to draw your senses inward to open your spiritual eye and to hear the sounds of your chakras. 
   This practice is non-denominational, appropriate for anyone. 
   Held in a lovely healing space, just walking in will bring you instant peace.  All are welcome.
    You may also want to check out my other Meetup, for a variety of spiritual programs:  http://www.meetup.com/Evolving-Beings/
