results.description:
Join the oldest established permanent floating Community Walk in Cambridge and Environs.  Join the Community Walkers and walkers from five other meetup groups.   Let's join 20+ others from six other walking groups for:

Since May 2012, there has been a regular walk around Fresh Pond at about an hour before sunset. Frequently, 20-25 walkers turn out for this walk, and you can too. There are a whole bunch of regulars, along with some new people.

We'll go out to dinner at a local pub or chinese restaurant - you can get a decent dinner for under $10.

Frequently, if we eat too much food, we'll go for another walk.

Come see why this walk is so popular. It's at a great time, the people are friendly, the parking is free -- no permit parking in Cambridge on Sunday, so you can park on Huron or Aberdeen Ave.

You can get there by T easily from Harvard Square, take the 71 OR 73 bus to Aberdeen Ave, then walk to the other end of Aberdeen Ave, and you'll see us there. We'll be next to the bridge, on the pond side of Huron Ave,at the intersection of Aberdeen Ave.

If you're late, and we've already started, start walking counter-clockwise. We'll be walking clockwise, so we'll surely bump into each other. We're the large group of vigorously chatting walkers.

Hope to see you there.

Shangri La is located at 149 Belmont Street, Belmont - please let the host know if you're coming, so we can get the right sized table.

results.description:
This introduction is primarily intended to help newer members who have attended fewer than three PGN events to understand how to effectively start using PGN.  It is also useful for other members who would like a more formal introduction to PGN.

Topics

- What does "personal growth" mean?
- Why PGN is not for most people
  -- And are you one of the few who can benefit from it?
- How can you benefit from PGN?
- How can you best try out PGN?
- The most critical basic navigation for PGN's site
- Problems some newbies have with PGN
-- and how to get around them

About the Personal Growth Network

The Personal Growth Network is a first-of-its-kind meta-organizer, bringing together diverse personal growth and positive psychology tools and techniques that are designed to help generally healthy people create greater joy and more success in all parts of their life.  Members can try out, learn, and practice numerous approaches; they can select some approaches for more in-depth study and application to their lives; they can practice, support, and share a particular approach with other members; and they can return to PGN to explore different approaches or to work on other parts of their life.  

PGN is also a community of like-hearted people who share an important, but not widely distributed, combination of values and characteristics (e.g., curiosity, willingness to learn, willingness to change habits) around consciously and proactively crafting a life well-lived.  For people with this important combination of characteristics, engaging with other members of the community can be fascinating, supportive, and affirming.

And finally, PGN is a toolbox with which members can create successful events.  Members can create workshops, practice groups, and social events through which they can share their journey, their gifts, their joy, their successes, their vision, and their interests.

About the Orientation Series

Given the enormous ambition and power of the Personal Growth Network, and its rapid growth, it is easy to feel a little overwhelmed at first, so we offer some "How-To" guides to maximize your utilization of the Personal Growth Network for whatever your goals may be.  


Our Orientations include:

For Participants
- Sun Mar 27: Newbie Introduction 
. . . (For new, infrequent, or curious members) 
- Sun Apr 10: User's Guide 
. . . (For active members of PGN) 
- Thu Mar 31: Customize PGN 
. . . (For reducing emails and focusing on your growth areas)


For Leaders
- Sun Apr 24: Intro to PGN Leadership 
. . . (For members considering leadership (offering events)) 
- Sun May 8: Create an Event on PGN 
. . . (For members ready to offer an event) 
- Sun May 15: Build Your Brand 
. . . (For leaders and organizers who want to build an identity.)

About This Particular Orientation:

There is no prerequisite to take this Orientation.  It is conceived of primarily for those members who are new to PGN, or have not tried out many events.  Some of the concepts introduced here are referred to in more advanced Orientations.

I will also try to address any specific questions that you post below. 

About The Technology:

This Orientation is offered as a "Zoom Webinar".  This means that you will need a computer, and you will need to be in a location where you can listen and watch without distractions.  (There will be opportunities for open discussion as well, so you may want to look presentable. )

The webinar software used is Zoom.  It runs on most platforms.  If you have not run it before, please click on the link a half-hour before to ensure that it is working on your system.

The link will be sent to you the day before the event.
results.name: PGN_Orientation: Newbie Introduction to PGN

results.description:
Perhaps the one topic shrouded in the most hype and baloney is aliens and UFOs. I feared taking on this topic until I heard Randal Montgomery recently on Coast to Coast AM (1-5am on 680). His book ALIENS and UFOs: Physical Psychic or Social Reality? is the focus of the talk. By Robin Harper, physics graduate, former electrical engineer, technical writer, and 25-year student of human nature, politics, and natural medicine.


I believe that ET craft have been visiting Earth for a long time and for moral reasons:

•  To save probably the most wondrous lifeforms and planet in the galaxy

•  To protect other living planets near us from plunder if we develop the technology to do so before we establish a long-term sustainable, peaceful civilization

We are very far from achieving this, but we may be near the Singularity in a few decades that gives us super AI and practical star trekking. I will hand out an infographic covering the usual UFO topics such as:

•  Debunking Roswell and so-called abductions

•  Sociology of UFO believers and skeptics

•  Causes of the 95% of sightings that become identified, sometimes as secret US or Russian aircraft

•  Some of the many reliable UFO sightings that indicate ET craft

•  How they got here, maybe self-replicating robot ships exploiting the theorized electric nature of gravity

However, I will focus more on:

•  Their motives for coming here, allowing a few sightings, not letting us have definitive proof, and not interfering (we may invent stuff better than theirs)

•  How they must have developed their civilization to keep it safe and sustainable for long enough to attain extreme capabilities

•  How we must do nearly the same to avoid extinction by our own foolishness or by ET protecting the planet and galaxy

Here are some thoughts on what they probably achieved to let them get here and perhaps have paradise at home:

•  World government stronger than any nation or cartel: Prevents conflicts by constant inspection, diplomacy, and threat of forced peace

•  Government serves the commons: Natural monopolies, state banks

•  No weapons of mass destruction: New technologies regulated by World government

•  Healthy environment and nature: Organic agriculture, slashed consumption, clean energy, make Half Earth wild (see References)

•  Population reduction: Women’s rights, education, birth control

·•  Transparent democracy: Candidate comparison tables written by private and public journalists, few government secrets

•  Truth in media: Make them produce and fact-check journalism that democracy requires

•  Education reform: Infographics not just paragraphs, AI tutors

•  Religious limitations: No state religions, schools teach science of religion

We must do the same, it’s not rocket science. The first step is to understand human nature and instincts that drive us so irresistibly and dangerously:

•  Tribal arrogance and bigotry

•  Mindless conformity and punishing freethinkers who resist

•  Fierce belief in myths and gods

•  Women’s nest enforcement, demanding cleanliness, order, and security and disparaging big ideas a man friend may have

I’m happy if anyone disproves something I contend.

References

ALIENS and UFOs: Physical, Psychic or Social Reality by Randal Montgomery, 2014

Physics of the Impossible: A Scientific Exploration into the World of Phasers, Force Fields, Teleportation, and Time Travel by Michio Kaku, 2008

results.description:
Join Leah Marie of The Mind Health Coach program as she discusses the effects of stress, anxiety and fear-based thoughts on the body and overall well-being.  Learn about self empowering techniques and different opportunities to explore holistic approaches to releasing stress, re-programming techniques to eliminate emotional triggers and gain freedom from fear-based thoughts. Bring love and light for healing back in your life.

The Mind Health Coach Program-BROADCASTS WEEKLY FRIDAY 10AM & 10PMETAnd Every 4th Sunday 8pmEST when Dreamvisions 7 Radio Network is at 1510am WMEX Boston


In this show, we explore ways to bring healing, peace, love and joy into your life, through meditation and holistic techniques that bring you to a higher level of consciousness and awareness. We look at life as an earth education and explore ways to bring that heavenly consciousness to our everyday earthly experience.

Host, Leah Marie, was directed to her spiritual path after having a near death and out of body experience in 2001 when she was injured in an equestrian accident where her body went into cardiac arrest and she was resuscitated by her father. She describes her journey to the other side as the most loving, peaceful and eye-opening experience of her life. During her time spent out of her body, she felt a higher level of consciousness that her soul experienced first-hand. She feels that it is part of her soul’s purpose to tell the story of this amazing trip and share the knowledge of another state of afterlife consciousness with others.
results.how_to_find_us: WMEX 1510 AM, mindhealthcoach.com, dreamvision7radio.com
results.name: Eliminate Stress and Fear-based triggers using Holistic Approaches to Wellbeing

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.
results.name: Monday Lunchtime Soccer (OUTDOOR)

results.description:
Tiling the Genome: Naming the Parts of Your Genome That Make You You

Event link HERE. This event is free and open to the public. Doors open at 4:45pm; lecture begins at 5.

Monday, Mar 28th, 5pm

Sheerr Room, Fay House

10 Garden Street, Cambridge

:: :: ::


A lecture by Alexander (Sasha) Wait Zaranek, chief scientist at Curoverse Inc. and director of informatics at the Harvard Personal Genome ProjectAlmost every cell in your body has about six billion characters (As,Cs, Gs, and Ts) of nearly identical DNA that make up your genome. A particular sequence of As, Cs, Gs, or Ts can indicate a growing tumor, a predisposition to a serious disease much later in life, or nothing at all. As millions of people get their genome sequenced, physicians and researchers as well as the individuals themselves will want to ask questions of these data. To ask questions we need a consistent naming scheme for parts of the genome. To address this we invented tiling—a technique that divides the genome into about 10 million overlapping, variable-length sequences, or "tiles," defined by their starting and ending unique 24-base tags. We will use examples from public data to show that tiling supports simple and consistent names, annotation, queries, machine learning, and clinical screening. Someday soon you may get to know the tiles in your own genome, and your doctor may use the information to realize precision medicine.

Part of the DNA lecture series. A larger, one-day public symposium on the topic, "The Past, Present, and Future of DNA," took place on Friday, October 2, 2015.
results.name: The Genome of YOU ...

Open edX was designed to be an extensible platform for experimenting with online learning techniques.  A key component of that extensibility is XBlock, the component API for courseware.  We'll have a quick overview of the technology behind XBlock, see a few notable examples of XBlocks, and also hear about JSInput, another extension technology available in Open edX.

John Eskew, architect on the platform team at edX, will tell us about XBlocks and how they work.

Louis Gudema, from service provider Appsembler, will demonstrate some XBlocks.

Colin Fredericks, project lead at Harvard, will explain how JSInput works.

Pizza will be provided! :)
results.name: XBlocks & JSInput

results.description:
Join us for a free film screening of (Dis)Honesty – The Truth About Lies: a documentary feature film that explores the human tendency to be dishonest. Inspired by the work of behavioral economist, Dan Ariely, the film interweaves personal stories, expert opinions, behavioral experiments, and archival footage to reveal how and why people lie.


Dan Ariely teaches at Duke University and is the founder of The Center for Advanced Hindsight and the co-founder of BEworks. Ariely's talks on TED have been watched over 7.8 million times. He is the author of Predictably Irrational and The Upside of Irrationality, both of which became New York Times best sellers, as well as The Honest Truth about Dishonesty.

*Space is limited to 85 people. Please RSVP. And... wait for it... be *honest* if you can't make it so that we can give your spot to someone on the waiting list*

Here's the schedule:  

• 6:00 - 6:30 Free food & drink while networking

• 6:30 - 8:00 Film screening of (Dis)Honesty

• 8:00 - 9:00 Folks are free to stick around for a short discussion of the film and networking 

Event Sponsor:

Pivotal Labs is a software development consultancy helping startups and enterprise build software applications using proven agile methods including extreme programming, lean product development, and balanced teams. Pivotal Labs has been a leader in agile philosophies for 20 years, helping small and large organizations transform their development practices by collaborating to build and launch market-tested, innovative products.

Pivotal Labs has generously donated the space in which the screening and event will take place, food, and drinks.
results.name: Film Screening of Dan Ariely's (Dis)Honesty

http://www.plantpurenation.com/


About this documentary:

"PlantPure Nationtells the story of three people on a quest to spread the message of one of the most important health breakthroughs of all time.

After renowned nutritional scientist and bestselling author T. Colin Campbell gives a stirring speech on the floor of the Kentucky House of Representatives, his son, Nelson, and Kentucky State Representative Tom Riner work together to propose a pilot program documenting the health benefits of a plant-based diet. Once the legislation goes into committee, agribusiness lobbyists kill the plan. Undeterred, Nelson decides to try his own pilot project in his hometown of Mebane, North Carolina."

Free. Fun. Starts here!

Welcome to the Marlborough Couch to 5K sponsored by ConnectingPoint Church. We love people in our community. We've helped over 400 people get off the couch and start jogging!


We have 2 groups: 

 1. Our Jogging Group has a goal of jogging a 5K. 

 2. Our Alumni Jogging Group has a goal of keep jogging for those who have jogged at least once season with us. 

We introduce people to jogging and getting fit. The program gradually moves you from walking at your own pace to jogging at your own pace. 

• FREE 10-week program to get you from the couch to running a 5K (3.1 miles) 

• Anyone from the community can participate

• Led by experienced runners 

• Monday through Thursdays 6pm-6:45pm; Sundays 8am-8:45am, with a goal of joining us 3 of these sessions per week 

• 45 minute time commitment

• Goal of jogging and finishing the Sprit of Hudson 5K in June 

Encourage those you love to get “off the couch” and join you in the great sport of running. Come have some fun! Bring a water bottle and join the group. 

Please arrive 15 minutes early the first night, so we can explain what you'll be doing on the Rail Trail, stretching out, etc.


 Please consult your doctor if you have a health or medical condition that prevents you from exercising. 

For more information please visit http://www.connectingpointchurch.org/couchto5k/

results.description:
Agenda

• 6:30: Networking & Pizza

• 7:00: Presentations

Presentation 1: Pay no attention to that WordPress behind your application


K. Adam White

The WordPress REST API project lays the foundation for the next generation of WordPress interfaces, but it also allows WordPress to function as a component within a larger network of applications and technologies. K Adam will share his experiences building with the WordPress REST API at Bocoup, showing how data from the API can be combined with Node and other JavaScript technologies to create non-traditional WP applications.

Bio: K. Adam White is a JavaScript engineer at Bocoup, an Open Web technology company in Boston, Massachusetts, where he writes web applications, contributes to open-source projects, and evangelizes for the web as an open platform for technology and collaboration. An artist and enthusiast photographer, K.Adam is also a WordPress core contributor, a (rarely seen) co-organizer of the Boston WordPress community, and the author of a Node.js client for the WordPress REST API.

Presentation 2: Thru a Designer's Eyes - Panel & Discussion

Not everyone that works with WordPress has a background as a graphic designer. Colors, fonts, white space, images...What makes a website look good?This panel will take a look at some websites and give their critique as designers and UI. We'll ask for suggestions from the group attending for the panel to review and discuss. Or if you're brave, suggest your own sites here and we'll take some from that list!

Panel:

Matt Ulvila (3thought)

Amy Kvistad (Amy Kvistad Design)

Mel Choice (User Interface at Automattic)

Each week, Elaine & Nicol alternate leading the group in a guided meditation to induce a deepened state of relaxation, healing on all levels.  You can achieve an expanded state of self and a higher state of consciousness, connecting you to the ALL that IS! 

Elaine and Nicol are able to connect with the most highest vibrations and frequencies of light that serves the group as a whole.  Your personal experience will be enhanced by the group setting. 

All levels of meditators are welcome to join us.  A sacred space is created to help you feel safe and comfortable. 

Please RSVP your intention on attending.  Cost is $5 at the door.  Doors open at 6:45pm with the group staring at 7pm! 

Visit our website for more info www.essencehealing.net

results.description:
Climbing MeetUp at MetroRock Gym in Everett. Toprope, sport leading, and bouldering available, including some tall walls up to 55 feet. Whether you're a new or experienced climber, join us for a fun and solid workout! We usually have people at all levels. Gym meetups are also a great way to make more friends for outdoor climbing. Plus Mondays are Ladies' Night: discounted admission. If you'd like to lead climb, don't forget to bring your rope :)

*** If you are new to MetroRock Gym and/or climbing, please see the FAQ below. ***

Please RSVP if possible; helps everyone to know others are coming.  Meet at the picnic table near bouldering area (usually the round one, furthest from the cubbies, if available) at 7 PM.  We usually wait a few minutes for people to show and make introductions, but if you arrive later and miss us at the table,  check the small whiteboard near the bathrooms and water fountain, for a description of what the Event Host (see RSVP list) is wearing that day, and come find us on the walls.  Don't be shy, make an effort to ask around and find the group; we're all friendly.  We usually climb until 9-9:30-ish, but if you'd like to secure partner(s) who can come earlier or stay later, feel free to post to the comment section below.

(NOTE: In the very rare case the Event Host doesn't arrive by 7, assume major traffic jam or other catastrophy, ask others nearby to find the group, make introductions, and go climb).

Full-access Day Pass:  $22.  Students, Military or Bouldering-Only Pass:  $18.  Mondays are Ladies Night:  Women's Pass $14 after 3 PM & also special class pricing.

For membership, gear rentals, and other programs and pricing available, or for directions, check the gym website:  http://www.metrorock.com/

Frequently Asked Questions for Newbies:

Q) How do I get to the gym?

A) See website for directions: http://www.metrorock.com/ If you're driving here for the first time, it can be tricky to find MetroRock Everett, especially in the dark! Use a GPS if possible. MetroRock is in a building opposite Boston Coach.   If you don't have a vehicle, the gym offers a shuttle service from nearby Wellington T Station; call the gym for schedule details.

Q) I've never climbed at MetroRock Gym before, what do I need to do?

A) You'll need to take and pass a belay test for rope climbing. There is a separate test for toproping and sport lead climbing (if you are interested in both). For toproping, if you are not confident you can tie a re-threaded figure-8 knot and double fisherman's backup knot and safely belay a climber using an ATC device, it is highly recommended you take the Basic Safety class. They will not allow you to climb on ropes without passing a belay test. Call MetroRock in advance to reserve your spot in the class, and ask them about any discounts or special prices they are offering. Also, you can rent basic climbing gear (harness, shoes, belay device, etc), if needed, at the gym.

results.description:
Our Book choice for March is My Brilliant Friend, by Elena Ferrante

A modern masterpiece from one of Italy’s most acclaimed authors, My Brilliant Friend is a rich, intense, and generous-hearted story about two friends, Elena and Lila. Ferrante’s inimitable style lends itself perfectly to a meticulous portrait of these two women that is also the story of a nation and a touching meditation on the nature of friendship.

The story begins in the 1950s, in a poor but vibrant neighborhood on the outskirts of Naples. Growing up on these tough streets the two girls learn to rely on each other ahead of anyone or anything else. As they grow, as their paths repeatedly diverge and converge, Elena and Lila remain best friends whose respective destinies are reflected and refracted in the other. They are likewise the embodiments of a nation undergoing momentous change. Through the lives of these two women, Ferrante tells the story of a neighborhood, a city, and a country as it is transformed in ways that, in turn, also transform the relationship between her protagonists, the unforgettable Elena and Lila.

Ferrante is the author of three previous works of critically acclaimed fiction: The Days of Abandonment, Troubling Love, and The Lost Daughter. With this novel, the first in a tetralogy, she proves herself to be one of Italy’s great storytellers. She has given her readers a masterfully plotted page-turner, abundant and generous in its narrative details and characterizations, that is also a stylish work of literary fiction destined to delight her many fans and win new readers to her fiction.
results.name: North Shore Book Club

results.description:
This is our brand new auxiliary meetup event.  This is a great opportunity to socialize and play games in a relaxed environment -- and best of all, there's no cap on attendance.

We are a casual group of people who enjoy playing complex board games -- the kind of board games that make you think. We play a variety of games, but the games at this particular event are going to be on the smaller side -- because those are often the games that work best in a cafe setting.

Our main meetup requires RSVPs due to heavy popularity and finite space.  This event runs simultaneously, two buildings away.  RSVPs are NOT required for this event.  RSVPs are still appreciated so the event hosts know how many people to expect, but you don't need to update them and can come even if you don't RSVP.

This event takes place once a week (alternating Mondays and Wednesdays), from 7:00 - 9:30 or 10.  Cosi closes at 10, but after 9:30, you are welcome to come and join the regular meetup at that point, no RSVP required.

Cosi Cafe has graciously allowed us to use their back seating area every week.  You are not required to buy anything from them, but their food is honestly pretty good, so please take advantage of them if you are hungry for dinner, soft drinks, or snacks.

We play whatever people bring, but you don't have to bring anything -- the hosts will always have a bag of games with them!  Some games that you might expect to see here include:

Red 7, Love Letter, Codenames, Pictomania, The Resistance, Avalon, One Night Ultimate Werewolf, Bang!, Glory to Rome, Innovation, Mottainai, Chrononaughts, Time Lines, Tash-Kalar

If you're looking for longer or larger Euros (like 7 Wonders, Puerto Rico, or Terra Mystica), check out our regular "Game Night" meetup.

If you haven't played these kind of games before, but think you'll like them, you're welcome too!  But be aware that you are NOT likely to find traditional American games (like Monopoly, Sorry, Risk, or Poker); heavy strategy or negotiation games (like 18xx, wargames, or Diplomacy); or pure abstract games (like Chess).

OUTBOUND (from Boston / from Park Street)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the front of the train. Cross the street. (If you take the escalator up, turn around first to see the street.) After crossing, turn left and walk about 20 feet to Cosi.

INBOUND (from Alewife / Porter / Harvard / Central)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the rear of the train. Take the stairs up, then up again towards the busy street, which is Main Street.  Turn left and walk about 20 feet to Cosi.

FROM BOSTON (or Memorial Drive) 
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading north (cross the river if coming from Boston).  Memorial Drive is the first cross street past the river; go past it. 
2) Take the first right, onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the first right after Memorial Drive.) 
3) Take the first right, onto Main St. 
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical.
5) One side of the parking lot has a bunch of buildings with a handicapped ramp leading into it.  Go up the ramp, through the walkway, and Cosi will be right next to you when you come out.

FROM CAMBRIDGE (or points west) 
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading south. 
2) Take a left onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the last left before Memorial Drive; there is a railroad crossing there.) 
3) Take the first right, onto Main St. 
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical.
5) One side of the parking lot has a bunch of buildings with a handicapped ramp leading into it.  Go up the ramp, through the walkway, and Cosi will be right next to you when you come out.
results.how_to_find_us: Steps from the Kendall Square Red Line, in the middle of the block.

results.description:
Q & A:


Q.  I have never played x-wing, can I still play? 


A.  Yes, we will teach and supply ships and materials.  

Q.  Should I bring something? 
A.  If you want, bring a game you feel comfortable teaching. There will be pizza and sodas served, feel free to bring snacks or beverages to share or chip in $5 to $10 for the pizza/beverages in the pizza cup.


Q.  Until when do you play games?  Can I arrive later than 7pm? 
A.  Until the last game of the evening ends, usually past midnight.  Yes, you can arrive later than 7pm, but you may have to wait for a new game to start if you do.

Q.  I really want to play XYZ game instead of X-Wing, can we do that? 
A.  Some people ask for interest in a particular game on the event comments below.  This may be the way to make sure you get to play the game you want.  The game room will accomodate more players doing other games.  Just make sure you have game partners for that game or that you are fine in joining the x-wing game if no other players show up for the other game.

results.description:
(Please note our new RSVP policy below.) 


We are a casual group of people who enjoy playing complex board games -- the kind of board games that make you think. We play a variety of games, most of which are Euro style games of medium complexity.  Games often last 90 minutes or more and involve juggling a lot of rules and factors in your head, to decide what to do.  However, there's also plenty of laughter and friendship involved.  If that sounds up your alley, we hope you'll join us.

Our weekly meetup is in a TERRIFIC space for games steps from the Kendall Square T, with easy parking, and lots of room to spread out in.  Full directions are below.  The building door does get locked in the evening, but there is plenty of foot traffic in and out.  If you expect to arrive later than 8:30, send Tucker a message earlier in the day, and we'll make sure someone is there to let you in.

Our meetups happen once a week (alternating Mondays and Wednesdays), from 7:00 pm onwards.  Our group has been running since 2007, and we have a large crowd of regulars as well as new members each week.

1. Due to finite space, you must RSVP to attend.


2. Please be considerate of others -- only RSVP if you are likely to attend.  Likewise, if you need to cancel your RSVP, please do so at least 24 hours before the event.  This allows enough notice for someone else to use your spot.

3. Please save loud and/or big games (like those with real-time arguing) for after 9:30, when the room is less full.  This allows us to accommodate more people, and play a greater variety of games.

We play whatever people bring, which typically includes a lot of Euros.  Here's a "tip of the iceberg" look at a few games that have been popular lately:

7 Wonders, Terra Mystica, Race for the Galaxy, Splendor, One Night Werewolf, Le Havre, Hansa Teutonica, Machi Koro, Concordia, Super Big Boggle


As you can see, there is some real variety.  A few of our regular attendees bring about 20-30 games between them, so there's always a lot to choose from.  But if you have a game you like, just bring it with you!

If you haven't played these kind of games before, but think you'll like them, you're welcome too!  But be aware that you are NOT likely to find traditional American games (like Monopoly, Sorry, Risk, or Poker); heavy strategy or negotiation games (like 18xx, wargames, or Diplomacy); or pure abstract games (like Chess).

Finally, a note about Settlers of Catan, Carcassonne, and Ticket to Ride.  These are traditional "gateway games" that many people play when they first discover Euros.  Although you will occasionally find those games at our meetups, many of us have played them to death and have become more interested in games with a little more complexity to them.

OUTBOUND (from Boston / from Park Street)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the front of the train. Cross the street. (If you take the escalator up, turn around first to see the street.) After crossing, proceed behind the T entrance (perpendicular to Main Street).  Building E25 is the brick building a quarter block down, across from the parking lot.

INBOUND (from Alewife / Porter / Harvard / Central)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the rear of the train. Take the stairs or elevator straight up. Proceed straight ahead (perpendicular to Main Street). Building E25 is the brick building a quarter block down, across from the parking lot.

FROM BOSTON (or Memorial Drive)
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading north (cross the river if coming from Boston).  Memorial Drive is the first cross street past the river; go past it.
2) Take the first right, onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the first right after Memorial Drive.)
3) Take the first right, onto Main St.
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical. Exit the parking lot at the rear (opposite from where you entered). Building E25 will be directly across the street.

FROM CAMBRIDGE (or points west)
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading south.
2) Take a left onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the last left before Memorial Drive; there is a railroad crossing there.)
3) Take the first right, onto Main St.
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical. Exit the parking lot at the rear (opposite from where you entered). Building E25 will be directly across the street.

Once you enter, Room 119 is just past the stairs on the right. There is a suggested donation of $1.00 that goes towards site fees and party supplies.  (When we have a raffle, you will also receive an extra raffle ticket as thanks for donating.)

Feel free to email with any questions -- we hope to see you at a meetup soon.



OTHER POLICY DETAILS:

If you would like to come but there are no spots, consider attending our alternative "Light Game Night" a few steps away at Cosi Cafe.  You can also sign up as "wants a spot" and receive emails from meetup if a spot opens up.

We know everyone has emergencies.  But consistent, inconsiderate use of RSVPs -- which includes being a "no show", cancelling in the last 24 hours, or constantly cancelling RSVPs -- will lead to being removed from the group.  Sorry, we still like you, it's just not fair to everyone else!

If you use a "+1" spot, you are responsible for all of the above for your +1.  Since you are using two spots, it is extra important that you are considerate about it.

NEW MEMBERS: Welcome!  We look forward to meeting you.  If you want to bring a friend, please have them sign up with their own account rather than using a +1.  Unfortunately, we've gotten a lot of no-show +1's from first time attendees, so we don't accept those anymore.  Sorry!

results.description:
Join us for an introduction to this unique Japanese martial art. Participants will all get a chance to practice some basic movements, explore a bit of the underpinning philosophy, and experience seated meditation. In short, we will have fun together learning about this martial way, one unknown to many in the United States. 

Shorinji Kempo is a relatively new martial art. It was founded just after WWII as part of a Zen Buddhist practice. Today, while the martial art has been separated from the religion, the practice of Shorinji Kempo remains true to it's Zen Buddhist roots, with philosophy and meditation still integral to the study in the dojo of hard (punches, kicks and blocks) and soft techniques (releases, joint locks and throws).

It really is for anyone who’s curious. Whether you're interested in investigating Christianity, you are a new Christian, or you just want to brush up on the basics - this is for you.

results.description:
If you ever wanted to select a specific area of your image to adjust the exposure levels or color saturation you know how painstaking and frustrating it can be. 

However, hidden away in the depths of Photoshop is the ability to select specific areas of your image based on its tone. With a little effort you can select just the shadows, or the highlights by using Luminosity Masks.

Luminosity masks are selections of tonal areas of your image that are perfectly feathered to blend with the rest of your image. 

Creating them is easy but You won't find it in the menus, neither will you find it in the tools. It's a barely advertised but essential technique that will revolutionize the way you work on your images. 

This workshop will introduce you to the technique and you will leave with a handout explaining exactly how to use the technique. While a basic understanding of curves, levels channels and layers is useful, it is not essential as Ian will explain everything in simple to understand language.

results.name: PHOTOSHOP:  Luminosity Masks

This month we will be reading Malice by John Gwynne. 

 From Goodreads, "The Banished Lands has a violent past where armies of men and giants clashed shields in battle, the earth running dark with their heartsblood. Although the giant-clans were broken in ages past, their ruined fortresses still scar the land. But now giants stir anew, the very stones weep blood and there are sightings of giant wyrms. Those who can still read the signs see a threat far greater than the ancient wars. Sorrow will darken the world, as angels and demons make it their battlefield. Then there will be a war to end all wars."

A weekly gathering bringing together Buddhist meditation practice and recovery. The group will meet weekly in the main practice room to:

~ Meditate with others who are in recovery or exploring recovery

~ Offer contemplations and readings which inspire our recovery and support our practices

~ Share our personal experience, strength and courage

~ Integrate the basic goodness of meditation with our commitment to recovery

'Sobriety is finding a new way of living that involves engagement where there was withdrawal; generosity where there was self-centeredness; community where there was isolation; joy where there was bitterness; trust where there was cynicism.'
  ~ Kevin Griffin, One Breath at a Time: Buddhism and the Twelve Steps

Open to all—meditation practitioners from all traditions and Twelve Step practitioners from all programs.

Leader: John R.  <a>[masked]</a>

Free/suggested donation.
results.name: Recovery Meditation

results.description:
(Please note: many of the friends who attend regularly are not Meetup members, so there are always more people attending that it says on the Meetup site.)

About This Meditation Meetup

We sit in silence for around 45 minutes, followed by discussion for around 30 minutes or so. The silent sitting is interspersed with some meditation instruction, perhaps a brief reading, a little simple inquiry, exploration or movement. Sitting posture is relaxed, either on a meditation cushion or a bench. It's not a rigid practice- move whenever you need to!

We meet every Monday night, 7:30 pm at the Cambridge Friends Meeting House. The Friends Meeting House is located at 5 Longfellow Park, Cambridge, MA 02138 You can find a very good map here: <a href="http://www.fmcquaker.org/FMC-Map_2006.pdf" target="_blank"></a>

http://fmcquaker.org/about-friends-meeting-at-cambridge/directions/

Parking is available after 6:00 in the loop off of Brattle St. that leads to the Friend's House, and there is a small lot in back of the Friend's House for those with limited mobility. After that, parking is a little tricky in Cambridge (lots of "resident only" signs), but you will find available parking on Mount Auburn St. near Friend's House and on Brattle St. as you head away from Harvard Square.

Coming by the T is a great option, with the Friend's House being a lovely 15 minute walk out of Harvard Square.

If you find you are running late, come anyway! The format is very relaxed and open— anyone interested in contemplative practice is welcome!

 

About Open Awareness Meditation Group

At the heart of these meditation sessions is the silent exploration of what we refer to as Open Awareness. We all know what it means to feel closed, limited, vulnerable, or separate. What is it like to allow ourselves to return to our natural condition of openness, presence, non-separateness and ease? This is what we explore in our meetings.

We have been meeting for over a decade, and those who lead the meditations have known each other and been practicing together for many years. They have all deeply explored a variety of traditions— for some it has been the Tibetan Buddhist practices of Dzogchen or Mahamudra, for others it has been the Indian traditions of Yoga, or Advaita, or what is currently referred to as Nonduality (some popular examples of this are Francis Lucille, Rupert Spira, Eckhart Tolle and Adyashanti). 

However all of these traditions ultimately point to the same truth, the truth of our basic awareness or presence which is beyond any tradition, practice or teaching. This is the presence we share, and the presence we are, beyond words. This is what we explore in our meetings.

This group is unique in that there is no specific guiding teacher, lama, or guru. We all meet as equals to question, share, and inspire each other to explore the Open Awareness we most deeply are. The meetings are suitable for newcomers as well as experienced meditators, and all are very welcome.
results.name: Open Awareness Meditation Group Meetup

results.description:
The Oneness Blessing (also known as Deeksha which is Sanskrit for "blessing" or "benediction") is the transfer of intelligent sacred energy - Divine Grace - which causes the heart to flower, heals relationships, quiets the constant chatter of the mind, opens the door to higher states of awareness and initiates a process of permanent awakening into Oneness where there is no longer a sense of separation and personal suffering. All that remains is causeless love, joy and peace in the present moment.

We start the circle the Chakra Dhyana followed by the Oneness Blessings. We allow time for integration of the blessings and sharing.

The Chakra Dhyana is an ancient technique from Tibet and India. It helps to enliven kundalini, a latent spiritual energy which when awakened flows through the Chakras, opening up higher dimensions in human consciousness. The meditation helps to expand consciousness in a way which relaxes the mind, balances the emotions and rejuvenates the body. The meditation includes the chanting of powerful mantras, including the "bija mantras" (or seed sounds) for the chakras, and a visualization of kundalini energy as a golden fluid flowing into the chakras.

Oneness Blessing is free, donations accepted for the use of the Wings Studio at Roots and Wings.

results.description:
This is where we start with OPM (Other People’s Money). Even sophisticated investors with several million to put to work can benefit from leveraging what they have. The world’s top individual investors like Warren Buffett and Donald Trump invest with other people’s money as the new rule. And we’ve already seen how banks, mortgage lenders, and the largest hedge funds use other people’s money to make more money. And it just makes sense. By multiplying what you have with leveraging you can reduce risk, enjoy more diversification and safety, and amp up returns. All at the same time. You’ve got to invest that money wisely and safely, with as much care as your own, if not more. But it can help you, and them too.

There are a number of ways to raise and pool funds. But before we dive into these, you’ve got to know your goals. And most importantly – your why. This is your compass.

Without your compass you are virtually guaranteed to end up at the wrong destination. And all it takes is to get off course by a couple of degrees and your destination can be thousands of miles away from where you wanted to go.

So why?

Why raise funds? Why invest? Why make more money?

Our goal at NNG is to build a note community by teaching investors how to capitalize on the foreclosure crisis by buying mortgage notes for pennies on the dollar. Purchasing mortgage notes is another alternative to buying foreclosure or owning rental properties.

Take your Note Knowledge to the next level and minimize your risk with education in this alternative investment strategy.

results.description:
Monday, March 28 CitySide Comedy Club is very proud to present Quincy Jones, seen on Ellen, NPR, GQ and more.

See Quincy's recent appearance on Ellen here: http://ellentube.com/videos/0-kkj1n36x/

Quincy Jones is a Los Angeles based comedian who can make any room fall in love with his craft, much like his namesake. Quincy moved to LA from Seattle to pursue a career in stand-up four years ago. Within his seven years of stand-up experience, Quincy has toured the country and played the best stages in LA, including shows with comedy legends like Bill Burr. In 2013 Quincy Jones was inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of fame (while our Quincy was drinking a Chai with almond milk in a Korea Town coffee shop). On July 3, 2015 Quincy was diagnosed with stage-four Mesothelioma cancer. He was given one year to live. Quincy is currently not strong enough to work his regular barista day job; his energy can only last a few hours at a time. On nights that he is feeling well he makes sure to hit the stages around Los Angeles, spreading laughter, as he preps for this stand-up special film shoot. While on stage, Quincy is cancer free.

Quincy will be filming his one hour comedy special at the Teragram Ballroom in Los Angeles on April 4, 2016. We at CitySide Comedy Club are thrilled and honored to have Quincy headline in preparation for the special.

This show is 100% FREE, but you can reserve a seat here: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/cityside-comedy-club-free-every-monday-at-cityside-bar-tickets-21040783550

Every Monday CitySide Comedy Club brings you the absolute best standup comics working today. With hilarious headliners, and frequent surprise guest comics, CitySide Comedy Club is the best spot for Standup Comedy in Boston on Mondays.
Doors at 8pm, show at 9pm. No Cover. 21+.

results.description:
Please register for Low-latency ingestion and analytics with Apache Kafka and Apache Apex (Hadoop) on Mar 28,[masked]:00 PM at: 

https://attendee.gotowebinar.com/register/6144492461887443972

This talk will cover a fully fault tolerant, scalable, and operational ingestion from Kafka using Apache Apex application, running natively in Hadoop. The talks will deep dive into technical details of the connectors in Apache Malhar. Details of production use cases will also be discussed. 

Agenda

9:00pm - Countdown for webinar 

9:15pm - Talk #1 will present how Apache Apex consumes from Kafka topics for real-time time processing and analytics. We will cover the features of the Apex Kafka Connector, which is one of the most popular operators in the Apex Malhar operator library, and powers several production use cases. We will explain the advanced features this operator provides for high throughput, low latency ingest and how it enables fault tolerant topologies with exactly once processing semantics. 

10:00pm - Q&A 

10:15pm - Talk #2 covers recently added support in Apache Apex Malhar for the new Kafka 0.9 consumer API. We will cover how the new API has simplified certain aspects of the connector, performance and scalability considerations when consuming data from Kafka with Apache Apex, interoperability with MapR streams and plans for future enhancements 

10:45pm - Q&A 

11:00pm - Demo 

11:15pm - Q&A 

Speakers:

- Siyuan Hua, committer of Apache Apex 

- Thomas Weise, committer and PPMC member of Apache Apex. A Hadoop veteran 

After registering, you will receive a confirmation email containing information about joining the webcast.
results.how_to_find_us: It is an online Webcast
results.name: Low-latency ingestion and analytics with Apache Kafka and Apache Apex (Hadoop)

Please note volunteers need to sign up for this event using EventBrite to be confirmed as a volunteer for this event. Thanks.

https://www.eventbrite.com/e/help-the-big-apple-circus-of-the-senses-tuesday-329-tickets-20809797665

Please share this with friends and family.


Circus of the Senses is a unique performance of the Big Apple Circus that provides children with vision or hearing impairments and other special needs an opportunity to experience the excitement of classical circus under the big top.


Please note you do not need to be single to help at this event.


The special features of this performance include a live, detailed Audio Description of the acts broadcast through wireless headsets, Braille and Large-print programs that contain vivid descriptions of each act, and American Sign Language interpreters stationed throughout the tent. After the performance there is a Touch Session, where a small, pre-selected, group of vision-impaired children are invited to come into the ring to meet our performers, pet some of the show animals and touch some of the show props and acrobatic equipment.


What we will be doing:

Volunteers will assist in handing out programs, assisting children from buses to tent, and helping with post show Touch Session. Note that we are requesting cell #'s at the Circus' request.

Dress Code:

Casual clothing and a good pair of comfortable shoes.

Directions: By Public Transportation (highly recommended)

Please Note Govt Center T is closed due to Construction

If you are coming by the T, Haymarket is also very close to Govt Center. It has the Green and Orange Lines. Just exit, cross the street and walk up the steps, or ramp to the plaza.

Map of alternative stations.

http://mbta.com/uploadedfiles/services/subway/GC%20Neighborhood%20Map.pdf

Driving:

Note that parking is limited and very expensive since this event is on a weekday. The circus will have limited discounted parking at nearby garage. More details will be sent closer to the event.

Use I-93 South and take Exit 24-A for Government Center. Stay in right lane on ramp. At top of the off ramp, proceed across Surface Road onto Clinton Street. At end of Clinton Street, proceed left onto North Street. City Hall is directly ahead across the intersection of North Street and Congress Street.

Driving From the South:

Use I-93 North and take Exit 23 for Government Center. Stay in left lane on ramp. At top of ramp, left lane becomes two lanes wide. Stay in lane marked for Government Center. This lane crosses Surface Road onto North Street. Follow North Street to intersection with Congress Street. City Hall is directly ahead across the intersection of North Street and Congress Street.

Driving from the West on Storrow Drive:

Storrow Drive Traffic should access I-93 South. Use I-93 South and take Exit 24-A for Government Center. Stay in right lane on ramp. At top of the off ramp, proceed across Surface Road onto Clinton Street. At end of Clinton Street, proceed left onto North Street. City Hall is directly ahead across the intersection of North Street and Congress Street.

Driving from the East or West on the Massachusetts Turnpike:

Massachusetts Turnpike (I-90) Traffic should access I-93 North. Use I-93 North and take Exit 23 for Government Center. Stay in left lane on ramp. At top of ramp, left lane becomes two lanes wide. Stay in lane marked for Government Center. This lane crosses Surface Road onto North Street. Follow North Street to intersection with Congress Street. City Hall is directly ahead across the intersection of North Street and Congress Street.

Driving from the East via the Sumner Tunnel:

Traffic using the Sumner Tunnel should stay in the left lane marked for Government Center. Left lane exit ramp splits in two. Keep to left at this split for Government Center. From the top of the ramp, turn left onto New Chardon Street and proceed to Congress Street. Take a left onto Congress Street (passing under the Government Center Garage) and proceed to the intersection with North Street. Boston City Hall is directly on the right.

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

Question:

This sounds like a great deal, but is it meant for those in need, as is the case with food banks? 

Answer:

• For this operation, there are "No qualifications - no limits!" 

Thanks to the efficiency and BI (business intelligence) of Fair Foods of Dorchester (FairFoods.org), founded about 35 years ago by self-reported vegetarian Nancy Jamison, we have way more than AMPLE food for any intended audiences, and the operation is bettered if MORE people take the food than if FEWER take the food. 

Therefore, there is NO QUALIFICATION (no test of need) and no limit to how much you can cart off (just pay $2/bag). 

That's why it's posted on a meetup like this (not merely on a volunteer meetup). 

* There are tens of thousands of college students who could benefit by saving some money on their weekly produce purchases. 
* There are tens of thousands (myriads) of homemakers and working individuals who could benefit by saving some money on their weekly produce purchases. 
* Lots and lots of seniors AND needy folks, and there's no operational shame in prudent fiscal management if you know that you can get quality produce at a far lower price. 

[The snag is that, unlike in grocery stores - or even in Haymarket, your variety of produce is severely limited here because you're getting what Fair Foods sends to any specific site; you are unable to select from a broader arrangement of vegetables and a broader arrangement of fruits.  Typically, you get about 7-11 different items - about 5-8 different vegetables and 2-3 fruits, and you're often 'gifted' with extra items - 30 ounce jug of fresh hummus or lentil salad or chickpea salads, pound of garlic, large one-lb plastic container of ground pepper, or lots of other 'big items' we don't typically buy.] 

Make us busy - very busy.

***********************

How does the Non-Competitive TennisNorthEast Partner Program Work?

Partner Program Basic Concept

  We connect you with up to 30 Men and/or Women based upon your playing region and skill level. These are tennis players who love the sport and joined the program to meet up with you on the courts. The Partner Program is less competitive as there are no champions crowned and no league standings. The program provides dedicated tennis partners who want to meet up with you on the courts.


 TennisNorthEast's tennis partner program is broken down to these playing regions: Boston - Brookline,  Boston - Cambridge,  Metro North,  Metro South,  Metro West - Burlington,  Metro West - Framingham,  Metro West - Newton,  North Shore.

 The partner program is a monthly subscription service. The Partner Program is ongoing and remains open as long as the weather is good enough to play outdoor tennis. This is NOT a doubles program.

Your Task-"Scheduling and Meeting up with the other players"

  You meet up with the players to play either a match or just hit around. TennisNorthEast's objective to ensure players are actively playing. We try to use an incentive system to push players along. Anyone who plays 3 different partners in a calendar month will get another month of service for free.

Where to Play?

  The league strongly suggests that players jointly choose a tennis court location convenient to both. We now geo-locate your program contacts which means you should receive partners closer to your preferred playing location. We provide an extensive list of tennis courts for each area, including details such as # of courts, lighting, hitting walls and links to google maps for directions. Members can submit court ratings on the overall condition, surface, lighting quality, facility management, and general comments regarding specific courts. This will provide players with up-to-date court information on new and existing courts. We encourage members to keep this list fresh and up-to-date.

Target Audience

  The Partner Program is for all level players. We encourage beginners to play in the Partner Program prior to playing in a league. We track the results of the Partner Program and may make skill rating adjustments based upon scores if necessary. Our program ensures fun, well-matched tennis partners for players of all levels.
Admin Note: This program typically has players from 2.0 to 3.5+ level enrolled. In most locations 4.0 and 4.5+ level players will not find this program worthwhile.

Cost to Participate

  The cost will be no greater than $9/month to participate in the program. Any player that plays 3 or more different partners in a calendar month will get another month of service at no cost. In some *NEW* cities the program will be free as we are trying to build a dedicated tennis playing community. For details on your city please just refer to your homepage.

Tennis League Network Donations

  Our business charter is based upon doing the better good for players health and society. For 2015, we will continue to donate 2% to 4% of the Tennis Partner Program Entry fees to Cancer Research Institute. As of 7/1/15 we've donated $9,500.

Join Today!!

  So Join Today and we'd be happy to find you dedicated tennis playing partners.

results.description:
We'll attend the CCI afternoon program with presenters from The Color of Water, an initiative created to address water inequality in Boston and the human right to water.  They'll share their work and have time for a conversation.


From the Facebook event:


Project Goal:
“We want all Boston residents to enjoy the Human Rights to Water and Sanitation. Boston should guarantee a lifeline supply of water to each household, make provision for emergencies to ensure that all residents have water, and protect our water sources from both pollution and privatization.”

Statement on Boston’s Water Status:
“For Boston's working people, especially those in communities of color and immigrant neighborhoods, there are many challenges. Water need not be one of them. But it is. Many more families in Dorchester, Roxbury and Mattapan live under threat of having the water shut off for lack of ability to pay than in Back Bay or Beacon Hill.”


Accessibility Information: 14 Beacon Street is wheelchair accessible, but the door to the building is heavy and does not have a button to open it.  Please let us know your needs so we can help make the event accessible for you.
results.name: Attend CCI Program: The Human Right to Water, and Water Inequality in Boston

Synopsis:

In the sci-fi thriller “Midnight Special,” writer/director Jeff Nichols proves again that he is one of the most compelling storytellers of our time, as a father (Michael Shannon), goes on the run to protect his young son, Alton (Jaeden Lieberher), and uncover the truth behind the boy’s special powers. What starts as a race from religious extremists and local law enforcement quickly escalates to a nationwide manhunt involving the highest levels of the Federal Government. Ultimately his father risks everything to protect Alton and help fulfill a destiny that could change the world forever, in this genre–defying film as supernatural as it is intimately human.

results.description:
Join us for our Inaugural event featuring ClearSky Data's CTO - Laz Vekiarides.

"Laz Vekiarides is the founder and CTO of ClearSky Data, the Boston based company that was recently backed by Akamai, Highland Capital, General Catalyst, Polaris and others.  ClearSky's global storage network simplifies the entire data lifecycle and delivers enterprise class storage as a fully managed service. Clients 'plug-in' to the network from their own data enter and receive all the promise of the cloud, such as on-demand scalability, ease of use and pay-as-you-go economics without giving up the tried and true benefits of traditional on-premise storage, like security, performance and availability.  Laz was previously the Executive Director of Software Engineering for Dell and a senior manager and architect at local firms EqualLogic, 3COM and Banyan Systems."  

Learn about the architecture their global storage network and engage in discussions around if, how and when this type of technology makes sense for an organization.
results.name: Inaugural Meeting - Rise of the Global Storage Network

results.description:
Wanted to update regarding parking.

There is plenty of free parking in the dirt lot across the street.

Hope to see you ALL on March 29th.


Atmel and Arrow present, From Maker to MarketPlace!

Maker to MarketPlace is a hands on training developed to introduce you to Atmel Studio 7 and the many features inside. The training is geared for those engineers who have already done programming and code development, who are looking to take that knowledge to the next level, or just simply learn about some great free resources available to expedite development. The Atmel team will demonstrate and review how to access and use some of the Key Features of Studio 7. 

 
Agenda: 

5:30 - 6:30   Networking and Food

6:30 - 8:00    Hands-On Training

8:00 - 8:30    Q & A and more networking

• Run an Arduino Sketch program, import to Studio 7 and convert to C++ code 

• Step through Studio 7 demonstrating where to locate key features and design tools 

• Review of the Atmel Data Visualizer which captures and displays run-time power data 
• QTouch Composer allowing you to seamlessly develop capacitive touch for you application 

Every participant will receive an Atmel Development Kit which will provide them with the ability to proceed in developing, testing and implementing source code to take their product to market. 

At the heart of the Maker Movement, Atmel® is enabling engineers, professionals and hobbyists to kick-start their latest projects from smart and securely connected devices for the Internet of Things (IoT), to robotics, thermostats, 3D printers and much, much more. Atmel guides the millions of Makers from getting started on the open source Arduino platforms based on Atmel microcontrollers (MCUs), to spreading the word through its millions of digital followers, all the way to getting it to market and transferring to Atmel’s professional integrated development platform.

Atmel Studio 7 features seamless one-click import of projects created in the Arduino development environment. Your sketch, including any libraries it references, will be imported into Studio 7 as a C++ project. Once imported, you can leverage the full capabilities of Studio 7 to fine-tune and debug your design. 


Atmel® Studio 7 has been updated to use the 2015 version of the Visual Studio Shell, enhancing not only the look and feel of the integrated development environment (IDE) but also the performance when working with large projects. 


Atmel Studio 7 is FREE of charge and is integrated with Atmel Software Framework (ASF) – a large library of source code and project examples. ASF strengthens Studio 7 by providing, in the same environment, access to ready-to-use code that minimizes much of the low level design required for projects.

The Atmel Software Framework, integrated into Atmel Studio 7, is a collection of production-ready source code, including 1,600 ready-to-use project examples, written and optimized by experts and tested in hundreds of production designs. Use these peripheral drivers, communication stacks and application-specific libraries to quickly and easily complete your projects.
The Atmel Software Framework works across all Atmel® | SMART ARM®-based, AVR UC3, AVR XMEGA® and megaAVR® devices and with both GNU and IAR C compilers. It supports over 300 Atmel microcontrollers, including more than 60 ARM Cortex®-M processor-based devices.
results.name: Maker to MarketPlace Hands-On Workshop

Free Public Speaking Workshop at WeWork hosted by BostonSpeaks.

Description:


No matter if you are a novice looking for a crash course in public speaking or a professional who wants to improve your communication skills, this workshop will explore how to effectively Prepare, Deliver, Close a presentation or speak off-the-cuff. Participants will be encouraged to engage in speaking and evaluation activities.


About The Host:


Trinh Nguyn, a Triple Crown Award recipient of Toastmaster, shares his tips and tricks on public speaking. He's here to show exactly what he did to stay focus at achieving his goals to become a better speaker.  He went from having his legs shaken delivering his speech to shaking his fear away at every speech.  Come join us to find out how he did it!

results.description:
5:30 - 6:00 PM - Pizza and Networking


Extending Solr: Packaging Common Sense

This year has brought us 10 years of Solr and the last few years have brought us more changes and surprises in Solr than we would have ever imagined: SolrCloud, replication rules, distributed TF/IDF, additional APIs to make development even easier. What could be left?

The rise of “open core” products (commercial products which use open source projects at their core) has made it possible for open source projects to both thrive and help businesses grow. We will take a look at a product from the commercial sponsor of Solr: Lucidworks Fusion. From its driving motivation to its architecture Fusion is meant to increase the adoption of Solr even as it makes it easier to accomplish many of the things that Solr does best. From connectors, to visualizations, to security, we will discuss how a product like Fusion will help drive the further adoption of Solr now and in the future.

Carlos Valcarcel has been a search geek since 2007 when he accepted a position at Fast Search and Transfer just prior to Fast being acquired by Microsoft. He has been an independent consultant, developer, and distributed systems architect for more years than he cares to think about.

Solr as a Graph Database using the Graph Query

This is an overview of the new Solr Graph Query. We will discuss the semantics of this new query operator in Lucene/Solr and how it can be used to solve real world knowledge graph problems. In addition, we will cover how to handle data that is a graph in nature and discuss items such as social networking search, recommendation engines, security filtering, and how to use knowledge graphs and ontologies to draw conclusions, all using the Solr Graph query.

Kevin Watters has been working with search engines since 2002 where he was a Senior Solution Architect at FAST and subsequently a Principal Engineer at Attivio. Since 2010, Kevin has been running KMW Technology, a professional services organization based in Boston that provides search and big data consulting services. Kevin is the author of the Solr Graph query and he also contributes to an open source robotics platform called MyRobotLab.
results.name: Extending Solr with Fusion / Solr as a Graph Database

results.description:
EAT TO THRIVE: 
10-week course to Life Long Healthy Habits Healthy Living 
with Betsy Bragg

* Tuesdays, January 26 -March 29  6:00 – 9:30 pm

  Come be motivated to change your life!!

Where:  
Arlington Senior Center Mural Room
27 Maple Street, Arlington MA

Upcoming course information – apply today – space is limited 
(online/phone[masked])  http://www.optimumhealthsolution.org

When: Tuesdays:  January 26 - March 29,  2016

Location: 
Arlington Senior Center Mural Room
27 Maple Street, Arlington MA

 Early Bird Special: Save $50 if registered by December 29

Fee includes 383-page manual, sprouting kits, DVDs to watch, 
and a five-course health-promoting meal each week.

Eat to Thrive

Class Dates:  Tuesdays, January 26 – March 29, 2016, 6:00 – 9:30 pm

Info Session:  Tuesday, January 5, 2016, 6:30 – 8:30 pm

Location: 
Arlington Senior Center Mural Room
27 Maple Street, Arlington MA

EAT TO THRIVE COURSE OPTIONS/TRACKS AND PRICING

1. AUDIT: This is for students whose goal it is to gain exposure to the subject matter. Whether they have an illness or simply a thirst for knowledge of the subject matter, they will be permitted to attend, borrow DVDs and participate.  They will be required to prepare and contribute to the five course meal. However, there are no attendance or written/oral requirements.  Fee: $555

2. REPEATING AUDIT STUDENTS:  (returning graduates) Fee: $355

3. HEALTH EDUCATOR CERTIFICATE: This track is for students whose goal it is to apply the knowledge from this course to a career path. Successful completion of this program will lead to an Optimum Health Solution (OHS) Certificate of Completion. Requirements for this course are attendance at 8 out of 10 classes; a passing grade on two take-home essay tests; and a presentation with hands-on learning for a group of at least 5 people (to be described more in detail on the website). Fee: $755 

4. REAL KIDS REAL FOOD HEALTH (RKRF) EDUCATOR CERTIFICATE: 
This track is designed for teachers or students seeking a career path in teaching upper elementary to middle school-age children and want to gain expertise in the subject area of healthy foods. Students enrolled in this certificate program will have an additional 6 hours of one-on-one teacher training with master educator, Betsy Bragg; students will learn kid-tested recipes and techniques for teaching and presentation; students will have the opportunity to observe other master teachers, participate in a practicum, and design their own lesson plan. Successful completion of this program will lead to an OHS RKRF Certificate of Completion.  Betsy’s background includes 48 years of teaching Elementary through University levels, M.Ed Stanford and Harvard Universities, M.A. Boston University, licensed in Special Education Lesley University, licensed in English Second Language University of Massachusetts. Fee $800. Repeating students (graduates) Fee $600

5. Eat to Thrive Educator Training Certificate: This track is designed for repeating students who want to teach a section of the OHS Eat to Thrive Program. In addition to the 10-week program, students will be given an additional 6 of hands-on training in all aspects of the curriculum and administration. As OHS plans to expand its Eat to Thrive program to other locations in Massachusetts, paid teachers will be required to hold this certification.  Prerequisite: Students must have taken an Eat to Thrive course and hold the Health Educator Certificate. Fee: $650
results.how_to_find_us: Upcoming course information: apply today; space is limited (online/phone 781-899-6664)  http://www.optimumhealthsolution.org
results.name: Eat to Thrive: 10 Weeks to Life Long Healthy Habits and Healthy Living

results.description:
Join us on March 29th for a talk by Andrew Jorgensen, a Senior Software Engineer at Twitter working on Answers, a real-time mobile app analytics product. Doors open at 6:00 PM, and the talk will begin at 7:00 PM.

In the 30 seconds that it takes you to read this, Answers will have processed over 30 million events in support of its actionable, insightful, and real-time mobile analytics dashboards. Real-time analytics are becoming increasingly important to understanding how users are using your mobile applications, and the amount of data created by mobile devices is increasing rapidly. In this talk, you'll learn how Answers leverages the lambda architecture and probabilistic algorithms to handle this torrent of information. We'll dive into how Answers uses Twitter’s new stream-processing technology, Heron, to efficiently process all that information with improved reliability, performance, and operability compared to other stream processing technologies. We’ll give a personal account of migrating from using Storm to using Heron for processing mobile events and the benefits we’ve seen so far.

Note: Press is not admitted into these events; please e-mail [masked] if you have any questions. Twitter reserves the right to refuse entry and remove any individual from Twitter's premises for disruptive or disorderly behavior. All guests are subject to show proof of valid ID.
results.name: Real-time Mobile App Analytics with Answers

results.description:
Thanks go to DataXu for hosting both the space and food and drink for this event!


Doors will open at 6PM for networking and food. Presentations will start at 6:45PM.


Lightning: Simeon Simeonov, founder & CTO of Swoop, will give us a preview of his upcoming Spark Summit talk: Idempotence makes big data systems simpler & saner. Unfortunately, it is rarer than Unicorn dust in Spark. In five minutes we will cover the What, the So What? and the O, Shoot! of this four syllable term leaving enough time for a brief prayer that Spark gets more of it soonish.

Feature: Nick Chammas will share his talk on “Flintrock: A Faster, Better spark-ec2”


spark-ec2 is a handy little tool for spinning up Spark clusters on EC2, but it has a few frustrating problems that are difficult to solve within its current architecture. In this talk, Nick will give an overview of Flintrock, a single-purpose command-line tool for launching and interacting with Spark clusters on EC2. Flintrock is open source and aims to be the spiritual successor to spark-ec2
