OPEN CARDS AND BOARD GAME NIGHT

ANTHING GOES TONIGHT - bring your board games, and your card games like Sorry, Yahtzee, Clue, Domino, Scrabble, Apple to Apples, Monopoly, Wizard, etc...

                        Tonight we'll play them all!

   Bring your decks of cards and let the games begin!

Come join the C&C crew over at Not Your Average Joe's in Medford for a open cards and board game night.  There is always conversation and dinner first but then we can split up and play whatever there is.

Whether you prefer board games, card games or party games (or just want to meet people!), Tuesday nights will be your opportunity! We welcome  new additions to the group, and it's great to see new friendships being made over board games...

Although we start playing around 6:30pm or so, early birds (Before 6pm) can take advantage of their half-price happy hour menu. These are full-portion sized appetizers for real cheap! If not, you'll still be able to take advantage of the monthly specials.

HOW TO GET THERE

This location is easily accessible from Rt. 16, Rt. 28 and Rt. 93, and is walking distance from the T, near the new Station Landing apartment complex. Here is a map of the area.

By Subway: Take the Orange Line to Wellington. Walk over the skybridge and cross through the parking lot. Upon exiting the garage, you'll see a building complex (SL75) across the street. Cross the street and take a right. Follow around this building and you'll find Not Your Average Joe's on the opposite side of the street.

By Car: If you are driving, be aware that Station Landing is at the intersection of Rt. 16 and Rt. 28, and you can enter the Station Landing complex from the north-bound side of Rt. 28, or the east-bound side of Rt. 16. There are a number of stores in the Station Landing complex -- look for the Margarita's, Starbucks or Not Your Average Joe's signs. NYAJ is located right off of Rte. 28. Although there is free parking all around the building, we recommend that C&C members park in the garage underneath the restaurant.

Welcome to the Marlborough Couch to 5K sponsored by ConnectingPoint Church. We love people in our community. We've helped over 400 people get off the couch and start jogging!


We have 2 groups: 

 1. Our Jogging Group has a goal of jogging a 5K. 

 2. Our Alumni Jogging Group has a goal of keep jogging for those who have jogged at least once season with us. 

We introduce people to jogging and getting fit. The program gradually moves you from walking at your own pace to jogging at your own pace. 

• FREE 10-week program to get you from the couch to running a 5K (3.1 miles) 

• Anyone from the community can participate

• Led by experienced runners 

• Monday through Thursdays 6pm-6:45pm; Sundays 8am-8:45am, with a goal of joining us 3 of these sessions per week 

• 45 minute time commitment

• Goal of jogging and finishing the Sprit of Hudson 5K in June 

Encourage those you love to get “off the couch” and join you in the great sport of running. Come have some fun! Bring a water bottle and join the group.

 Please consult your doctor if you have a health or medical condition that prevents you from exercising.

results.description:
Jibran ​is excited to talk (or scream) about why Boston is the best place in America to launch a startup through the lens of the impact MassChallenge startups that have gone through the MC accelerator​ have had.​ 

He may even reach into his dope meme stash and hand out promo codes for application discounts to the 2016 MassChallenge accelerator program. 

About Startup Climbing Boston

#StartupClimb brings together rock climbers of all levels that are in the startup community. The talk is free, and it's $19 to climb you can pay when you come in, just mention you're with the startup group. 


Agenda

6:45PM Registration

7:00PM Speaker talk

7:30PM - ? Closing time is 11:30 PM, climb as long as you like!

Speaker Bio

At MassChallenge, Jibran is not only responsible for coordinating with the Events, Partnerships, and Marketing teams to make sure the entire world knows what’s going on in the startup accelerator through digital content, but he also dedicates himself to amplifying the amazing stories the MassChallenge startups have to tell on a daily basis.

Prior to MassChallenge, Jibran was an intern for the Alliance to Restore Business Leadership. Jibran is a graduate of Suffolk University, where he received a B.A. in Political Science and History. 

Sponsor

Brooklyn Boulders (#BKBS @bkbsomerville on Twitter / Instagram) Somerville is a 40,000 sq. ft. rock climbing and fitness facility in Somerville, Massachusetts that offers a new type of community space that blends state-of-the-art climbing terrain with art, culture, music, and entrepreneurship. Brooklyn Boulders is a dynamic creative community. BKB Somerville strives to maintain a strong connection with its community in various efforts such as inviting local graffiti artists to display their work and planning our youth events around local school schedules. Whether you’re a seasoned 5.13 climber or just found yourself interested in trying something new, come to BKB Somerville and find what you’re looking for.

results.description:
Are you curious about programming or thinking about pursuing a career in software engineering? 

Then RSVP on this meet-up page for this 2-hour Intro to Coding class happening in the Boston area at CIC Boston. Learn the basics of programming, do hands-on exercises, and meet new people. All for free!

The class is being taught by MakerSquare, which runs some of the top coding schools in the country.

Class officially starts at 6:30pm, but please arrive at CIC Boston by 6:15pm to mingle with your fellow classmates and settle in. We will end at 9pm, with the last 30 minutes being an optional Q&A session.

What will I learn during the class?

This beginner ­level class will contain several instructor-guided exercises. The class will cover the following topics:

   1. Overview of programming 

   2. Intro to data & data structures

   3. Basics of functions

We ask that you read the Prerequisites section before the start of class and bring your own laptop (Windows, Mac or Linux) with Google Chrome installed.

What is MakerSquare Boston?

MakerSquare is a three-month full-time school for software engineering. By teaching computer science fundamentals and modern web languages like JavaScript, we prepare students to join top flight engineering teams.

We have campuses all over the country, and are excited to be opening a campus in Boston. The free Intro to Coding class is to introduce more people to the wonderful world of programming and to get the community excited about the launch of our full-time class in Boston in July 2016!

Questions? Email us at [masked].
results.name: Free Intro to Coding Class (Tues March 29, 6:30-9pm)

results.description:
The New England Progress User's Group

This meeting will be a hand on workshop.  Please bring a laptop.

We will meet at 6:30 pm for Pizza, Drinks and Networking. 

The workshop will begin at 7 pm.

Thanks to David Cleary and the whole Progress team for offering this workshop and continuing to support the NEPUG reboot.

Introduction to PASOE WEB and HRWeb Application

Starting from OpenEdge 11.6, Progress have enabled support for WEB Transport. By this support, one can easily run their existing WebSpeed code in PAS for OE Server in the new Multi-session Agent. In-addition to that, users can also develop applications in a new Object model called  OpenHTTP which provides support for all the recommended HTTP Verbs which was missing in WebSpeed.

Workshop Summary

We will be running an application that is “SpeedScript”,  KendoUI + AngularJS based UI which has its' back end written in WebHandlers and business entities. We call this application  HRWeb and in this demo we will be using Progress Developer Studio to run through of steps of developing, deploying and running WEB transport based applications in PAS for OE.

Workshop Details

1.  Deploying SpeedScript Application in PAS for OE

2.  Adding WebHandlers support for the existing application

3.  Configuring OERealm Security and URL pattern security

4.  Running WebHandlers on  a Stylish UI using kendoUI + angularJS
results.name: Hands On WorkShop: WebSpeed and PASOE

results.description:
Presented by David Loutzenheiser


Getting there is as much a part of the adventure as the destination.


The Swiss Alps are synonymous with Switzerland and the main draw for tourists and locals alike. An incredible network of signed bike routes and hiking trails have been developed not only through the Alps but connecting to all the cities in the country. Join David Loutzenheiser on a journey through Switzerland by foot and bike exploring how the journey is just as exciting as the destination. Also learn about an effort to bring such a trail network to the Boston area. 

Potluck Details: Starts at 6:30pm. Participation in the potlucks is optional, yet useful for that post-office work hunger. Homemade dishes are welcome, store bought goodies & takeout are equally welcome. Plates, bowls, cups, cutlery, napkins and drink pitchers will be supplied. The auditorium has a kitchen if you need to do any re-warming or prep (stovetop, oven, microwave, sink & fridge). Please bring your own cooking pots if needed for stovetop.


Parking: Nearby underground parking is available at the Boston Common Garage, located underneath the Boston Common. Access is off Charles St, between the Public Garden and the Boston Common. We have discount parking passes for $9 (50% off normal rate!) More info about the Garage is here: http://bostonparking.spplus.com/boston-boston-common-garage-zero-charles-street-parking.html#Tab_coupon-rates

Building a website is easy. So easy in fact that we'll start from scratch and build a complete website using my favorite tool - WordPress. I've been using WordPress for about 5 years and it remains my go-to for all different types of projects. Probably because so many other options have come and gone while WordPress remains a work-horse with staying power.

What is it that you want to do? Make a real estate site, make a blog on your favorite topic, or sell your awesome quippy t-shirts online - All of this is a breeze with Wordpress. 

Knowing the fundamentals of WordPress has allowed me to say yes to so many projects that I couldn't have taken on otherwise. Now it's time for you to have the same confidence to tackle your goals online.

What has taken me years to figure out (I'm a slow learner) - I'll share with you in an evening, so let's dive in and come out the other side with a site that all of us will help build together (I'm serious about the last part - together we're going to launch an internet company in an evening).

See you soon,

Erik

results.description:
We start off chatting about our work, including setting goals for ourselves (which is entirely optional but super helpful!), and then we write. That's what it's all about. As simple as the idea is, it's amazing how much more you can get done simply by being in the presence of other writers at work. The baked goods don't hurt, either.


There is power for laptops, and some of us use pen and paper. Your choice! Bonus: there's no Internet access, so you can omit a huge distraction without even trying. And, although we are not a discussion group, there are many areas where people can go if they want to talk without being disruptive.

Please click here for detailed directions! The school can be a bit of a maze and I don't want anybody getting lost.
results.name: Quite Write: Writing Night!

results.description:
***PLEASE ADD YOUR TOPIC SUGGESTIONS TO THE COMMENT SECTION OR MESSAGE AN ORGANIZER***

This will be the seventh session of our Current Events meetup series (**NO prior attendance required). We aim to have reoccurring discussions moving forward so we can stay abreast of local, national, and global anti-racism issues together as a community. We have seen a surge in media coverage within the racial justice movement over the past year. It can get overwhelming trying to keep up with all the stories, events, anniversaries, policies, and debates that touch on racial justice in some way. Let's pool our collective knowledge and discuss what's going on - locally, nationally, and globally - within the realm of anti-racism. This will be a great opportunity to share our sources, our stories, and our knowledge to keep everyone informed of the way things are changing, and unfortunately, the many ways in which things are staying the same.

The topics will change from month to month depending upon what's happening in the world, but many stories may carry over. Considering a current event you'd like to discuss at the meeting? Have a helpful article you'd like to share? Want to look at a story from an unexplored angle? Know of a local story/action/event that may not be getting coverage? Great! Feel free to post in the comments section below or email one of the facilitators with your ideas. We hope you'll come to this session willing to share your thoughts and knowledge on the events of the past month. If not, feel free to listen, learn, and participate in some really important conversations. Looking forward to seeing you all there and continuing this discussion series! 


Possible March Current Events:

- Boston Public School Students Walk Out

- Hillary Clinton reactions to black activists

- ...add your suggestions to the comment section!


Review from past months:

- Scalia

- Entertainment: Beyonce halftime show, oscars, cam newton, 

- Boston Latin Schools battle racism

- Flint Water Crisis
results.how_to_find_us: Dial:  #-1-9

Your goal should be to have this service take care of your Tenants so you can get to the next level!

Mike Hurney, MassRealEstate.net

results.description:
Susan Rose will be leading this meditation. The name of the meditation is The Mountain Meditation. Our event start time is 6:45pm. But please arrive early to settle in. 

Our schedule:
6:30pm - It's great to arrive early to ask questions and find a good seat. We have chitchat time starting around 6:30. Come hang out with us and feel free to peruse the store.
6:45pm - Class starts.
Please note: We lock the door at 7pm. At 7pm, you are already 15 minutes late for class, so please do not disturb the class by trying to enter or knocking.
8:00pm - Class ends. 

What happens during class: 
   The 75 minutes that we spend together will include: 
           1) discussion about meditation and mindfulness 
           2) instructions on how to meditate 
           3) experience the Mountain Meditation 
The length of the meditation itself will probably be about 15 to 25 minutes long. No previous experience is required; the meditation will be easy for beginners to understand. 


More info: 
Our website has more information about the history of our Community Meditation Nights.              http://www.mindfulboston.com/classes/#/community-meditation-nights/

What to bring:
It's fine to just show up as you are.
Yet, please be aware that (as you can see in the pictures) most of us do sit on the floor. Some folks choose to bring their own pillow for sitting on the floor, but there are no requirements to bring anything.
If you require a chair for health reasons, make sure to RSVP and write "please reserve a chair for me" in the comments section below. We have about seven chairs, and typically 20 to 30 people participate.
results.name: Community Meditation Night- Mountain Meditation

Below is the text from the bulletin for this event:

"Waltham Connect is offered twice a year by First Parish in Waltham, a Unitarian Universalist congregation. This time we will look at the issues of Multiculturalism and economic equity. We will explore how immigrants and people of color are affected economically in terms of employment, education, housing, access to services and more. There will be time for you to engage in conversations with the other participants and to learn from perspectives of our panelists. Free and open to the public. Refreshments will be served after the conversations.

Our featured panelists will be:
- Rev. Thomas St. Louis, of the New Covenant Haitian Church (more info to come)
- Ben Kreider is a PhD student at the Heller School for Social Policy and Management at Brandeis University. In his research, he studies how low-wage workers in the U.S, particularly immigrants and workers of color, organize to build power. Ben has been a political, labor and community organizer for over 15 years."
results.name: Join the Conversation: Waltham Connect  Multiculturalism and Economic Equity

results.description:
INSPIRING SOLUTIONS FOR DIFFICULT TIMES                                                                                                     a meditation class series 

TUESDAYS | MARCH 22nd - APRIL 26th


7:00 - 8:30pm

Sometimes life can become overwhelming with difficult and turbulent events. At such times, peace can feel far away. However, just as the center of a hurricane is perfectly still, through meditation we can learn to build a place of peace within. From this inner space, we can make good decisions that foster harmony and happiness for ourself and others.

Join us in this practical course to learn simple and effective meditations for becoming more peaceful and at ease in everyday life. By creating peace within, we can share this with our community, our city and our world. Each class is beginner friendly- feel free to drop-in to any class in the series or try to attend each one!

Feel free to drop-in to any or all of the meditation classes in this series! No need to pre-register. 

with Kadampa Buddhist Teacher, Kyle Davis


Cost | $10 per class / $5 students & seniors.  Members FREE! 

Location | 179 Green Street – Boston, Jamaica Plain, MA 02130  

meditationINboston.org

This Meetup is intended for intermediate level players or higher, which means:Yankee C and above level, players with firm understanding of game strategy. Should be able to play 5-1 and 6-2 formations, have a good grasp of skills (passing, setting, hitting) and be able to move around to cover areas of the court. Play should consistently be bump-set-spike.



If you'd like to play, please do the following:


1. Send an email to Kory using the following URL: http://www.meetup.com/volleyball-122/message/?recipientId=8675200

2. In the message please indicate the date of event and your preferred position so we can make sure we have the right mix. ( If I don't know your position already)

Note that sending an email does not guarantee a spot to play; spots are only guaranteed if you receive a positive confirmation email. We will do our best to make sure the event is co-ed, have setters,  and incorporate a couple new members who want to join as well.

The location for this volleyball meetup is at the Orient Heights Community Center located at 86 Boardman Street in East Boston. Kory and Wing will be hosting these Tuesday night volleyball meetups.

This event is free if you are a member of Boston Community Centers. If not, it's a one-time $20 membership fee that is valid for a year. The Community Center is a short walk away from the Orient Heights T Stop on the Blue Line and also has plenty of parking. When you drive up, turn at the Mariott Hotel Sign and park in the lot or further along the fence.

As always, please remember:

- Respect the RSVP system (Don't show up expecting to play without a confirmed RSVP)

- The gym is open before the event to warm up, so please arrive a little early if you would like to warm up and stretch as we would like to start the game promptly from 7:00PM

- If it looks like you won't be able to make it or will run late please cancel your RSVP in time for someone else to join.  Event day/last minute cancellations and no shows will jeopardize your participation in future events.

QUESTION FOR MARCH: Where did you experience the craziest weather?


Our concept is simple: meet other travelers or expats, chat about where you've been and where they've been, and get inspired for your next trip. Everyone with an open mind and sense of adventure is welcome, whether you're a travel novice or an experienced travel junkie. 

This month we'll meet at Tavern in the Square @ Porter Sq. results.description:
"Form is emptiness; emptiness also is form. Emptiness is no other than form; form is no other than emptiness." 

-Excerpt from The Heart Sutra 

Join Lama Rod Owens as he continues to explore the meaning and importance of the Heart Sutra. On the evenings when Lama Rod teaches, he will be available at 6:00 PM for Personal Practice Dialogues: A small group discussion open to any practitioner with the goal of dialoguing about issues in personal practice that may not be able to be explored in the regular gathering at 7:00. If you would like to see him at 6:00, send him an email: [masked].

Lama Rod Owens is a graduate of the traditional 3 Year Retreat program at Kagyu Thubten Choling Monastery where he received his teaching authorization from his root teacher, The Venerable Lama Norlha Rinpoche. He is currently a resident teacher with Natural Dharma Fellowship in Cambridge, MA and is pursuing his graduate studies in Buddhism at Harvard Divinity School. He has served as the Lama and Program Director of Kagyu DC, a Tibetan Buddhist Dharma Center and community in Washington, D.C. Lama Rod specializes in applying the teachings of Mahamudra meditation in exploring racial and gender constructs, healing woundedness from trauma and other violence, as well as integrating spirituality and sexuality. Lama Rod is also a practicing reiki master.

Please note: most of the friends who attend regularly are not Meetup members, so there are always more people attending than are signed up using this web site.
results.name: Exploring The Heart Sutra (cont.) with Lama Rod Owens

results.description:
This is the follow-up novel to Atkinson's "Life After Life", which we read for a previous meeting.

We'll be calling ahead for a reservation, so please keep your RSVP up to date!


"Talk about being your own tough act to follow! Having accomplished a near miracle with Life After Life, in which she used a literary-do-over trope to tell the story of a British woman living between and after the two World Wars, Kate Atkinson now dares to write a companion novel that focuses on Life’s heroine Ursula Todd’s brother Teddy. Never mind that careful readers of the first book came away with the impression that Teddy most often turned up dead, in this one he’s an old man trying to come to grips with his post-War life and with a modern world and family. Switching back and forth in time (Atkinson can’t seem to help it...) between memories of his childhood and his present, Teddy emerges as a befuddled and somewhat stodgy old-man version of himself, a startlingly oblivious husband to stalwart Nancy and a wittily rueful father to a grown up daughter (“Viola was the solitary arrow they had shot blindly into the future, not knowing where she would land,” Teddy thinks. “They should have aimed better.”) Teddy never quite got over the War and he suspects that the “fact” of his being alive is as arbitrary as Ursula’s demise(s). (“He had been reconciled to death during the war and then suddenly the war was over and there was a next day and a next day. Part of him never adjusted to having a future.”) Scenes from his past bring back Ursula and other characters from the earlier book so that readers who’ve come this far with Atkinson will feel a tiny thrill of recognition; but new readers needn’t fear they’re missing the joke. There’s way less gimmick here than in the earlier book, and sometimes I almost longed for more; it was so provocative. But whether read alone or as a follow up, A God in Ruins is a novel to savor, another beautiful, tender and sly Atkinsonian glimpse into the world of a so-called ordinary mid-century British family."
results.name: Literature and Libations - A God in Ruins by Kate Atkinson

results.description:
In this FREE mini-workshop, you'll learn specific tools that you can use right away to master intimate connections that are meaningful and loving. 

Spend time with a group of like-minded friends (old and new) exploring what it means to live a life filled with love! 

If this feels scary to you and you've been holding yourself back, this workshop is for you! 

Discover what's in your way of having the most satisfying relationships including effective communication, and great sex. This workshop will focus on our innate ability to open to a greater love inside ourselves - that can be shared with others: a skill that when learned and practiced, enhances all of our relationships. 

Feeling deeply connected to yourself and your heart provides a deep sense of peace. 

You’ll learn specific tools that will:

• Enhance your ability to identify core wants, needs and desires
• Cultivate communication for healthy relating
• Become more intimate with yourself and others - with ease!
• Stay in a place of love when it’s most difficult


In this free mini-workshop, you’ll have the opportunity to connect with others through a variety of exercises designed to open your heart and support you in sharing authentically with one another.

Come and get a taste of what you’ve been craving in a totally safe, warm, loving and non-sexual environment. Learn more about what the Human Awareness Institute has to offer.

results.description:
Kurt Gray discusses The Mind Club: Who Thinks, What Feels, and Why It Matters … in conversation with Daniel Gilbert

This event is free and includes a book signing; no tickets are required.

Tuesday, March 29th, 7pm

Harvard Book Store - 1256 Mass. Ave., Cambridge

:: :: ::

Harvard Book Store welcomes psychology professors KURT GRAY and DANIEL GILBERT for a discussion of Gray's book The Mind Club: Who Thinks, What Feels, and Why It Matters, co-authored with Daniel M. Wegner.About The Mind Club

Nothing seems more real than the minds of other people. When you consider what your boss is thinking or whether your spouse is happy, you are admitting them into the "mind club." It's easy to assume other humans can think and feel, but what about a cow, a computer, a corporation? What kinds of mind do they have? Daniel M. Wegner and Kurt Gray are award-winning psychologists who have discovered that minds—while incredibly important—are a matter of perception. Their research opens a trove of new findings, with insights into human behavior that are fascinating, frightening and funny. The Mind Club explains why we love some animals and eat others, why people debate the existence of God so intensely, how good people can be so cruel, and why robots make such poor lovers.

By investigating the mind perception of extraordinary targets—animals, machines, comatose people, god—Wegner and Gray explain what it means to have a mind, and why it matters so much.Fusing cutting-edge research and personal anecdotes, The Mind Club explores the moral dimensions of mind perception with wit and compassion, revealing the surprisingly simple basis for what compels us to love and hate, to harm and to protect.

 “Daniel Wegner was among the world’s cleverest, wittiest, and most beloved social psychologists. The Mind Club is genuinely novel, with brilliantly conceived studies on some of the deepest issues the mind of man can ponder.” - Steven Pinker, author of The Stuff of Thought and How the Mind Works

“Daniel Wegner’s final book is a masterpiece made ever more precious by his untimely death. Thankfully, his brilliance and wit live on—in these pages, and in his collaborator and protégé, Kurt Gray, who presents their ideas with clarity, depth, and style. The Mind Club is not to be missed.” - Daniel Gilbert, author of Stumbling on Happiness

Purchase the Book: Featured event books will be for sale at the event for 20% off. Thank you for supporting this author series with your purchases.

Wayne Petersen: King Philip Came Over For Good Spaghetti Sauce
A cryptic title for a bird club presentation: Perhaps, but what does it mean? It can be a useful memory crutch for recalling the taxonomic categories of Kingdom, Phylum, Class, Order, Family, Genus, Species, and Subspecies. Unfortunately some birders fail to appreciate how these categories can enhance or improve their understanding of their birding activities. Most useful in this hierarchy is the Family category because if a birder can at once place an unfamiliar species into its proper family, he/she has taken a major step toward making a correct identification. This presentation will briefly examine how the scheme described above functionally operates, and will focus specifically on the significance of learning avian families and their characteristics.

results.description:
Meditation practice gives us a chance to step away from the busy-ness of our day-to-day lives. It provides space for us to be free from reaction, from expectation, from doing, and step into the gentle space of being.

This weekly practice consists of 25-30 minutes of guided Vipassana meditation followed by a brief discussion. Vipassana meditation encourages us to experience each moment exactly how it is, fostering presence and awareness.

In this practice we allow thoughts, emotions, and all other stimuli to surface. We become a witness of these, cultivating a space of non-attachment and revealing a deeper connection with one's inner self.

Newcomers to meditation and long-time practitioners are welcome to attend. This is a FREE practice. There is a suggested donation, but that is not required to attend.

We are meeting every Tuesday night from 8:00 PM to 10:00 PM practicing Modern Arnis, WC, and SCJ flow drills and Self-Defense skills.

All levels are welcome!  For ages 15 and up.


The price is $15.00 /per person /per meetup. The first meetup is free.

Please wear loose fitting, comfortable cloths suitable for working out.

Please do not wear shoes that you've worn outdoors on the wood floor.



Instructor's Background

Alix Lavaud has been training Martial Arts for over 45 years and is a master of Modern Arnis, Pien San Wing Chun Kung Fu, and has extensive training in Small Circle Jujitsu.  He also humbly owns the rank of Lakan Apat (a 4th degree BLACKBELT ).


Lineage

Modern Arnis :  Remy Presas  -->  Alix Lavaud

Wing Chun:  Henry Mui  -->  Alix Lavaud

Small Circle Jujitsu:  Wally Jay -->  Alix Lavaud


Philosophy

 Go With The Flow ...

Some Quotes we Love

“If your mind is empty, it is ready for anything. In the beginner’s mind there are many possibilities, but in the expert’s there are few”
― Shunryu Suzuki


“Everything is perfect and there is always room for improvement.”
― Shunryu Suzuki

“We must exist right here and right now!”
― Shunryu Suzuki

Benefits of Martial Arts

1.  Mental Benefits

14.  Improvement in many other Areas of Life

results.description:
Ongoing class in Medieval and Renaissance Longsword in the tradition of Johannes Lichtenauer.


The Longsword is the iconic fantasy Knight's sword - a two-handed, straight blade with a cross guard. The weapon may seem to be simple at first but is in reality a weapon of finesse and skill.


The class covers all the basics of footwork, attacks and defenses. Drills are developed from simple to complex; from rigidly choreographed to open-ended. Timing, distance and judgement are developed.


All classes begin with a Strength & Conditioning program designed to physically prepare one for fighting with the sword. Elements develop agility, core stability and power.

Please note volunteers need to sign up for this event using EventBrite to be confirmed as a volunteer for this event. Thanks.

https://www.eventbrite.com/e/the-big-apple-circus-of-the-senses-wednesday-330-tickets-20810047412

Please share this with friends and family.


Circus of the Senses is a unique performance of the Big Apple Circus that provides children with vision or hearing impairments and other special needs an opportunity to experience the excitement of classical circus under the big top.


Please note you do not need to be single to help at this event.


The special features of this performance include a live, detailed Audio Description of the acts broadcast through wireless headsets, Braille and Large-print programs that contain vivid descriptions of each act, and American Sign Language interpreters stationed throughout the tent. After the performance there is a Touch Session, where a small, pre-selected, group of vision-impaired children are invited to come into the ring to meet our performers, pet some of the show animals and touch some of the show props and acrobatic equipment.


What we will be doing:

Volunteers will assist in handing out programs, assisting children from buses to tent, and helping with post show Touch Session. Note that we are requesting cell #'s at the Circus' request.

Dress Code:

Casual clothing and a good pair of comfortable shoes.

Directions: By Public Transportation (highly recommended)

Please Note Govt Center T is closed due to Construction

If you are coming by the T, Haymarket is also very close to Govt Center. It has the Green and Orange Lines. Just exit, cross the street and walk up the steps, or ramp to the plaza.

Map of alternative stations.

http://mbta.com/uploadedfiles/services/subway/GC%20Neighborhood%20Map.pdf

Driving:

Note that parking is limited and very expensive since this event is on a weekday. The circus will have limited discounted parking at nearby garage. More details will be sent closer to the event.

Use I-93 South and take Exit 24-A for Government Center. Stay in right lane on ramp. At top of the off ramp, proceed across Surface Road onto Clinton Street. At end of Clinton Street, proceed left onto North Street. City Hall is directly ahead across the intersection of North Street and Congress Street.

Driving From the South:

Use I-93 North and take Exit 23 for Government Center. Stay in left lane on ramp. At top of ramp, left lane becomes two lanes wide. Stay in lane marked for Government Center. This lane crosses Surface Road onto North Street. Follow North Street to intersection with Congress Street. City Hall is directly ahead across the intersection of North Street and Congress Street.

Driving from the West on Storrow Drive:

Storrow Drive Traffic should access I-93 South. Use I-93 South and take Exit 24-A for Government Center. Stay in right lane on ramp. At top of the off ramp, proceed across Surface Road onto Clinton Street. At end of Clinton Street, proceed left onto North Street. City Hall is directly ahead across the intersection of North Street and Congress Street.

Driving from the East or West on the Massachusetts Turnpike:

Massachusetts Turnpike (I-90) Traffic should access I-93 North. Use I-93 North and take Exit 23 for Government Center. Stay in left lane on ramp. At top of ramp, left lane becomes two lanes wide. Stay in lane marked for Government Center. This lane crosses Surface Road onto North Street. Follow North Street to intersection with Congress Street. City Hall is directly ahead across the intersection of North Street and Congress Street.

Driving from the East via the Sumner Tunnel:

Traffic using the Sumner Tunnel should stay in the left lane marked for Government Center. Left lane exit ramp splits in two. Keep to left at this split for Government Center. From the top of the ramp, turn left onto New Chardon Street and proceed to Congress Street. Take a left onto Congress Street (passing under the Government Center Garage) and proceed to the intersection with North Street. Boston City Hall is directly on the right.

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

Marketers can learn from software developers to harness — rather than struggle against — the dynamics of a digital world.

Scott says of Hacking Marketing, “My goal was to help marketers at all levels — even those with no technical background or inclination — adapt marketing management to the wild and wonderful whirlwind of a world now dominated by software.”

“When you realize that marketers are now paddling water up to their chins in websites (software), analytics (software), social media (software), marketing automation (software), interactive content (software), mobile apps (software), and so on, it starts to seem obvious. Software has eaten the world — and marketing too.”

“To effectively harness the digital forces of software, we must not only innovate what we produce in marketing, but innovate how we produce it too.”

“It’s time to rethink marketing management for a software-powered world.”

How You Can Discover, Develop, and Deliver Winning Ideas - Dr. Liz Alexander 

Not all “ideas” are created equal. How do some people manage to easily find “winning” ideas? Why is it important to know what category your ideas fall into, so you can take the correct action to develop them? How can you ensure your idea will be compelling enough to others? 

Why attend this webinar:

1. What best-selling authors can teach you about coming up with relevant, compelling, and intriguing ideas.

2. How to use the Ideas Matrix to establish the right category (and action) for your ideas

3. Why do some ideas take hold and others don’t? Using a well-researched, five-factor model to ensure you can communicate the advantages of your idea to your target audience

results.description:
Do you VEGETABLE-TARIANS want all the OTHER people (even if they have not committed to be vegetarians) to eat fresh produce?  Then help us - each Wednesday late afternoon - bag vegetables (and some fruit) for the neighbors in Mission Hill.  Usually there are also freshly-baked loaves of bread, also (baked that morning - Jessica's Bakery).

It's an assembly line, then take home a bag (or two) of produce for yourself. 


Bring your business cards, smartphone, or notepad, and prepare to exchange contact info with other volunteers you like.  Volunteers come from several sources (not merely this meetup or others:Craigslist, Pharmacy School, School of Public Health, etc.) 

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
VOLUNTEERING for $2/bag of produce in Mission Hill
Tobin Community Center, 1481 Tremont Street
Mission Hill, Roxbury
(between Brigham Circle and Roxbury Crossing T stops)
Boston, MA 02120 - <2 blocks from Orange Line T Each Wednesday, from 4:00 - 6:00 pm (indoors in bad weather)

We will be VOLUNTEERING for the weekly Wednesday late afternoon $2/bag of produce in Mission Hill.

When you volunteer,
YOU will ALSO TAKE HOME one or two of those "$2 bags"!
We've had 55 volunteers, and we've had 7.  Workloads vary!

Fair Foods provides a 20-22 bag of produce for the Mission Hill neighbors so they can eat like me - on produce. The neighbors only need to pay' $2 for the bag.

Volunteers unload the truck, set up 3 banquet tables, set up the food in order of desntiy (potatoes on bottom - tomatoes and bananas and berries and kale on top), then fill each bag (and 'stack' them upright by one another - for the 'paying neighbors' to pick up (for $2).


We arrive around 4 pm (maybe as late as 4:30 pm) and work until 6 pm (can leave as early as 5:30 pm if we've finished).

In the FRONT of the Tobin Community Center, 1481 Tremont Street (between the Brigham Circle T stop - GREEN E-Line - and the Roxbury Crossing Orange Line T stop), behind the wrought iron fence.

Wear comfortable clothing that allows you to move flexibly and to actually work, lifting heavy bags of food. 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 
Tobin Community Center 
1481 Tremont Street, Boston, MA

results.name: VOLUNTEERING for distributing $2/bag of produce in Mission Hill

results.description:
Do you VEGETABLE-TARIANS want all the OTHER people (even if they have not committed to be vegetarians) to eat fresh produce?  Then help us - each Wednesday late afternoon - bag vegetables (and some fruit) for the neighbors in Mission Hill.  Usually there are also freshly-baked loaves of bread, also (baked that morning - Jessica's Bakery).

It's an assembly line, then take home a bag (or two) of produce for yourself. 

Bring your business cards, smartphone, or notepad, and prepare to exchange contact info with other volunteers you like.  Volunteers come from several sources (not merely this meetup or others:Craigslist, Pharmacy School, School of Public Health, etc.) 

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
VOLUNTEERING for $2/bag of produce in Mission Hill
Tobin Community Center
1481 Tremont Street - inside the front entrance
Mission Hill, Roxbury
(between Brigham Circle and Roxbury Crossing T stops)
Boston, MA 02120 - <2 blocks from Orange Line T Each Wednesday, from 4:00 - 6:00 pm (indoors in bad weather)


We will be VOLUNTEERING for the weekly Wednesday late afternoon $2/bag of produce in Mission Hill.

When you volunteer,
YOU will ALSO TAKE HOME one or two of those "$2 bags"! 
We've had 55 volunteers, and we've had 7.  Workloads vary!

Fair Foods provides a 20-22 bag of produce for the Mission Hill neighbors so they can eat like me - on produce. The neighbors only need to pay' $2 for the bag.

Volunteers unload the truck, set up 3 banquet tables, set up the food in order of desntiy (heavy food, such as potatoes or onions, on the bottom - lighter, more perishable foods, such as tomatoes and bananas and berries and kale on top), then fill each bag (and 'stack' them upright by one another - for the 'paying neighbors' to pick up (for $2).

Some arrive as early as 3:30 pm (you don't NEED to do that, but you're welcome to do so; OUR meetup's attendees - it's posted on 6 meetups - are often there early, and you can chat).

We (MOST of us) arrive around 4 pm (maybe as late as 4:30 pm) and work until 6 pm (can leave as early as 5:30 pm if we've finished).

In the FRONT of the Tobin Community Center, 1481 Tremont Street (between the Brigham Circle T stop - GREEN E-Line - and the Roxbury Crossing Orange Line T stop), behind the wrought iron fence.

Wear comfortable clothing that allows you to move flexibly and to actually work, lifting heavy bags of food. 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Question:
This sounds like a great deal, but is it meant for those in need, as is the case with food banks?

Answer:
No qualifications - no limitsWe have way more than AMPLE food for any intended audiences, and the operation is bettered if MORE people take the food than if FEWER take the food.

Therefore, there is NO QUALIFICATION (no test of need) and no limit to how much you can cart off (just pay $2/bag and $1/loaf of bread).  That's why I post it on a meetup like this.
Make us busy - very busy.

results.description:
Hi everyone,

We have scheduled our next UG meeting!

This event will include a session on Alteryx integration with Microsoft products and how to user Alteryx Designer together with Power BI, SQL Data Warehouse, Azure Machine Learning, and Microsoft R Server. This session will focus on demos and practical tips, and leave you with instructions for how to download the Microsoft Starter Kit that includes the samples. This event will also have a special guest speaker presented by Dunkin' Brands on franchise planning. 

Agenda

5:00pm - 5:10pm: Welcome and Introductions

5:10pm - 6:20pm: Joint Alteryx and Microsoft Integration Session

6:20pm - 6:50pm: Dunkin’ Brands Franchise Planning Use Case

6:50pm - 7:00pm: Questions and Closing Remarks

WHEN Wednesday, March 30, 2016 from 5:00 PM to 7:00 PM (EDT)

WHERE

Slalom Consulting - 316 Stuart St. Suite 300, Boston, MA 02116
results.name: Q1 Alteryx UG Meeting

results.description:
Amazing progress can be made just by talking about a project or problem aloud for 20 minutes. It's even better if you have an attentive listener to help you brainstorm ideas. This is peer debugging. We'll split into groups of two or three and take turns improving our lives.

Here are a few prompts if you'd like to pick topics in advance:

• Are you currently working on any projects that you'd like to improve or streamline?

• Is there anything you've been thinking you'd like to do but haven't gotten around to doing?

• Is there something you dislike doing yet find yourself doing anyway? 

• Has your mind been repeatedly wandering to the same thing lately? 

• Are there any skills or habits that you would like to develop? 

Our usual schedule is 


• 5:30-6pm Welcome everyone and discuss progress  on goals from last week. Order drinks and appetizers or dinner. 


• 6-7:00pm Focused discussion and work on our topic for the week. In addition to discussion of the theory, we really want to do exercises and make progress on real problems.


• 7-7:30pm Conclude and set individual goals for next meeting 


• 7:30-... Chat, mingle and leave whenever

Please bring something to write with and on.
results.how_to_find_us: We usually reserve a table in the back left. It should be easy to find.
results.name: Wednesday Workshop: Peer Debugging

results.description:
LET'S MEET AT THE KINSALE IRISH PUB FOR DRINKS AND FUN!!!

The Kinsale is located in Government Center in the heart of Boston. During the day, it's a favorite lunch spot for workers from many of the surrounding businesses, as well as City Hall.

At night, locals and visitors mingle in the lively bar while in our dining room guests enjoy a meal from our eclectic and highly acclaimed menu.

The Kinsale was designed and built in Ireland. The interior is warm and cozy, with beautiful Celtic motifs and fine Irish craftsmanship from floor to ceiling.

The Kinsale features free live music in the bar. And in season, you can enjoy a pint or an entire meal at one of our sidewalk tables.

So come on out, toss your responsibilities away and kick back with a tasty beverage drink and good conversation. You know you want to.

results.description:
The role that robotics play in medicine is critical and growing. Robots provide training for medical professionals, assist them during surgeries, and are part of implanted devices and prosthetic limbs. We have three speakers who will introduce us to the vast array of robots in medicine. Greg Fischer will discuss real time imagery during a surgery leveraging robotics compatible with Magnetic Resonance (MR). Greg Loan will discuss using robotics to develop highly realistic models for surgeons in training. And finally Jeff Duval will tell us about his work to develop powered prosthetic limbs. 

Rough agenda: 

6:00: Networking and Pizza 

6:30: Greg Fischer, Professor of Robotics and Director of Automation and Interventional Medicine at WPI

6:45: Greg Loan, Biomedical Simulation Engineer at MGH

7:00: Jean-Francois (Jeff) Duval, Research Scientist in Biomechatronics at MIT

7:20 - 7:30: 1 min pitches from audience. Need help? Looking for a job? Let us know. 7:30 on: Stay to chat, seconds on pizza.

Parking is provided free by our host, Vecna.
results.name: Robotics in Medicine

group.name: Robotics Interest Group (RIG): A MassRobotics Initiative

results.description:
Historian Alex Goldfeld explores the lives of people of African descent in the predominantly white Massachusetts Bay Colony, including Sebastian Kane, Dorchester’s first black landowner. He also shares his original research on Boston’s New Guinea neighborhood and examines what black life was like in Dorchester, Roxbury, and other parts of New England over three centuries ago. Goldfeld is Historian of the North End Historical Society in Boston. He leads tours, teaches classes, and conducts research on the North End. Goldfeld also served as Director of Operations at Boston's Museum of African American History.

Free
results.name: The Black Community in Colonial Dorchester and Boston

results.description:
Big data to be demystified for Boston area recruiters & talent sourcers for free on the evening of Wed. Mar. 30.


Andrew Gadomski is a guru in applying big data to sourcing/recruiting. The non-profit Boston Area Talent Sourcing Association is excited he’s coming to Beantown for BATSA’s 6th quarterly learning event to share his insights with you FREE.  If you don’t quite understand what data analytics can do for you in sourcing, you have to attend this!  He will demystify the tech with some real-world examples. Join the 110 people who have already pre-registered (did I say the event is free?) while seats remain at 

http://batsa6.eventbrite.com (full agenda & details there, too)! 

Plus we’ll have a cool spin (we're calling it BATSA Voices) on the peer-to-peer roundtables on various sourcing topics that everyone benefits from. Free pizza, beverages, snacks, desserts and prizes, too, thanks to our sponsor Avature.

P.S.  It’s OK if you haven’t attended a BATSA free sourcing learning event before (and you’re welcome to share this w/external colleagues, too).
results.how_to_find_us: see Directions section at http://batsa6.eventbrite.com
results.name: Register free for BATSA sourcing learning event #6

results.description:
Jerry Heneghan: UNC School of Pharmacy

Jerry Heneghan is professor of the practice and director of the Center for Innovation in Pharmacy Simulations at the UNC Eshelman School of Pharmacy. He leads CIPS in the development of simulation tools to enhance all phases of education and pharmaceutical research including medication discovery, delivery optimization, assessment, and practice.

Heneghan is also the Chief Design Officer (CDO) for BioMojo LLC, a woman-owned small business. Prior to joining UNC, Heneghan was the principal investigator for the BioGears human physiology engine. He was the founder and CEO of Virtual Heroes Inc. [masked]) and served as an executive producer for the America’s Army Game Project. Heneghan also worked at Red Storm Entertainment, Interactive Magic and served as a U.S. Army AH-64 helicopter pilot.  

Advanced Realtime Tracking

PLEASE NOTE: unfortunately our presenter has come down with a serious illness and won't be able to present this evening. We'll work on getting this presentation rescheduled.


Advanced Realtime Tracking is the world’s leading manufacturer of optical tracking systems for Virtual Reality (VR) in industrial applications. In addition, ART provides solutions for industrial measurement, medical applications and Motion Capture for ergonomics. ART also offers a variety of unique custom tracked input devices, such as our Flystick and Fingertracking products which have been specifically designed to optimize navigation and interaction with the major VR software applications. ART also provides the world’s only dedicated solution for unobtrusive optical tracking inside multi-sided projection systems.

At VR Meetup we will show the SMARTTRACK, a fully integrated solution for tracking systems up to 8ft, and ARTTRACK5, our high-end solution for large tracking volumes. Furthermore, a prototype for finger tracking with vibro-tactile feedback will be demonstrated.


PLEASE NOTE: Our venue requires our guests to sign in with a photo ID at the security desk. When you RSVP you'll get a pop up question; please enter your full name as it appears on your ID. Thanks for your cooperation. All attendees must RSVP in advance. Boston VR is a 501c3 non-profit organization and all ticket proceeds will go towards having more VR events in Boston!

Schedule

6 - Doors open, demos begin, pizza is served thanks to ART & Jerry Heneghan

7:00 - 8 - Jerry Heneghan UNC Presentation

8 - 8:15 - Demo intros & announcements

8:15 - 9:30 Demofest!!

9:30pm - Come with us to the afterparty at State Park 

Demos

VR KIX - A new HMD!

Hieroglyph - Collaborative VR meets Ancient Egypt

VR Web Browsing on the Samsung GearVR


Desolus

Archean

VirZOOM

Volunteers Needed!

We need help greeting guests and in return for working a 30 minute shift you'll get a free ticket to the event and also a "fast pass" so you can go to the front of the lines at the demos. If you're able to volunteer please send a private message to Jeff Bail and you will be manually added to the RSVP list.

Parking

One Kendall Square Garage 
Technology Square Garage

Cambridge Center East and West
results.how_to_find_us: Please use the main entrance and check in at the desk with a photo ID
results.name: Jerry Heneghan: UNC School of Pharmacy

results.description:
These meetups are cross posted into other groups. So you get to meet even more people!!! We will be playing this time, they have great food at a great price!

All are welcome to attend. Please order your food up stairs before coming downstairs.

Feel free to bring games, we are open to learning new and FUN games. Or you can just come and watch while talking and making friends. I ask that everyone that comes brings a friendly competition with the realization that we are here to have fun. You may also bring friends along.

We will have a wide variety of games making it easy to pick something that is more your speed. If you are unfamiliar with them you are always welcome to watch or we would be happy to teach you a new game. It is fairly common for more than one person to be learning a new game at a time, and we love to teach!

If you are shy and or this is your first meetup this is the best way to break the ice and make some new friends. So come on out and lets play

Games:
Cards Against Humanity
Loaded Question
Headbands
Jenga
Telestration
Uno and many more.

Standard Card Games:
I will have a few print out on how to play games with regular cards like; Spades, Jim Rummy, Blackjack (21), Speed, War, Slap Jack, and more.

Anyone... found yelling at another will not be allowed to continue to join this game night period.

Parking:Parking can be a hassle but street parking is available on surrounding streets in Harvard Square which is free parking. There is also a lot across from Charlies.

results.description:
Come join me to explore these two exhibits that were guest curated by actor Steve Martin!! 

The Idea of North
The Paintings of Lawren Harris

March 12, 2016 – June 12, 2016
Saundra B. and William H. Lane Galleries (Abstraction) (Gallery 332)

Above: Lawren Harris, Mountains in Snow: Rocky Mountain Paintings VII, about 1929. Oil on canvas. The Thomson Collection at the Art Gallery of Ontario. © Art Gallery of Ontario. © Family of Lawren S. Harris.Lawren Harris (1885–1970) was a pioneering modernist whose visionary paintings have virtually defined 20th-century Canadian art. His scenes of an evocative northland, isolated peaks, and vast expanses of shimmering water are considered essential images of the country. This exhibition—guest curated by collector, actor, writer, and musician Steve Martin and organized by the Hammer Museum (Los Angeles) and the Art Gallery of Ontario (Toronto)—will include approximately 30 major paintings of Harris’s idealized northern landscapes from the 1920s and 1930s, one of the most significant periods of the artist’s career. The exhibition draws from the AGO’s substantial holdings, as well as from major public and private collections across Canada—including the National Gallery of Canada and the McMichael Collection—and is the first major solo exhibition of Harris’s work to be shown in the United States.


http://mfas3.s3.amazonaws.com/styles/banner_grid-9_retina/s3/1929_MountainsinSnow_RockyMountainPaintingsVII_ThomsonCol_4x3.jpg?itok=reSE7lDu

Lawren Harris: Modern Connections from the MFA Collection

March 12, 2016 – June 12, 2016
Saundra B. and William H. Lane Galleries (Gallery 334)

http://mfas3.s3.amazonaws.com/styles/banner_grid-9_retina/s3/SC202963_4x3.jpg?itok=_oPNNPeT

Gain further insight into Lawren Harris and connections to his US contemporaries in nearby galleries in the Art of the Americas Wing’s third level.

The MFA’s outstanding collection of American modernism offers a special opportunity to create a strong dialogue between major works by Lawren Harris and other modern American paintings, photographs, and works on paper. In Gallery 334, the MFA’s traditional home for paintings from the Lane Collection, Steve Martin, a knowledgeable and avid collector of American modernism, selected works that resonate with his understanding of the work of Lawren Harris as an important modern painter of the Americas. Martin came to the MFA in September to view the American paintings collection in storage, looking at works by artists such as Arthur Dove, Georgia O’Keeffe, Rockwell Kent, and Marsden Hartley, and discussed the various connections between American modernism and Harris’s work. The final group of works on view has been shaped by Steve Martin in collaboration with the MFA and Andrew Hunter, curator of Canadian Art at the Art Gallery of Ontario.

The Robert and Jane Burke Gallery, 335, includes works on paper by Lawren Harris relating to two paintings he sent to the International Exhibition of Modern Art, held at the Brooklyn Museum in 1926, as well as works by artists like Alfred Stieglitz, Max Weber, Georgia O’Keeffe, and Joseph Stella, who were also represented in the 1926 exhibition, with different selections. This installation explores how, through an alternate lens of city, industry, and nature, artists of the United States were contemplating similar themes of spirituality and stillness that Harris sought in his paintings of the North.

Above: Arthur Garfield Dove, Square on the Pond, 1942. Wax-based paint on canvas. Gift of William H. and Saundra B. Lane and Henry H. and Zoe Oliver Sherman Fund, M. Theresa B. Hopkins Fund, Seth K. Sweetser Fund, Robert Jordan Fund and Museum purchase. © Estate of Arthur G. Dove.
results.name: MFA Free Wednesday Lawren Harris

Hello ASL Enthusiasts!

A number of folks living NORTH of Boston have asked about an ASL SOCIAL. Let's make this happen!

On WEDNESDAYS, starting October 29 - 6pm to 8pm - I / we will be at the NORTH SHORE MALL Food Court.

While technology has improved the way people communicate, "Deaf Social Clubs" are slowly disappearing. This is a way to start bringing REAL social interaction back!

Please join us for a casual, relaxed, no-pressure two-hour Social, where we can chat, tell stories, get to know each other, and meet new people (or old friends!). Friends, Fun and Food!

A warm welcome is extended to all Deaf & non-Deaf people: folks in the Deaf Community, CODA's, Interpreters, ASL students, parents of deaf children AND their children, ASL professors/teachers, Relay Operators, Deaf services workers- EVERYONE!

This will be a "SOME ASL KNOWLEDGE and ABOVE" Social, because not all of us are ASL-fluent! "Voices- Off" -- we'll all laugh & learn WITH and FROM each other!

WHAT: ASL SOCIAL CLUB
WHERE: North Shore Mall Food Court, PEABODY,MA
DAY/TIME: Wednesdays, 6pm - 8pm
WHY: To meet like-minded people, socialize using ASL, tell stories, and have good time!
WHO: Anyone who wants to chat using American Sign Language!
HOW TO FIND US:  We'll be sitting on the couches closest to the "walkway" side of the Food Court, not hidden inside the food court, so easier to locate us!

If you have any question, please contact Connie or Paul I., through the EMAIL LINK via BOSTON ASL profile page.

PLEASE, if you would be good enough, RSVP either "YES" or "NO" so I know who to look for!

CHEERS!

Connie Cassidy / Paul I.

PEACE...
results.why: ASL is the third largest "foreign language" in the U.S.; ASL is fun to use; ASL is NOT English, but does "borrow" from the English language.

The role that robotics play in medicine is critical and growing. Robots provide training for medical professionals, assist them during surgeries, and are part of implanted devices and prosthetic limbs.

Robotics Interest Group (RIG) has three speakers who will introduce us to the vast array of robots in medicine. Greg Fischer will discuss real time imagery during a surgery leveraging robotics compatible with Magnetic Resonance (MR). Greg Loan will discuss using robotics to develop highly realistic models for surgeons in training. And finally Jeff Duval will tell us about his work to develop powered prosthetic limbs.

6:00: Networking and Pizza

6:30: Greg Fischer, Professor of Robotics and Director of Automation and Interventional Medicine at WPI

6:45: Greg Loan, Biomedical Simulation Engineer at MGH

7:30 on: Stay to chat, seconds on pizza.

Parking is provided free by our host, Vecna.

HIIT is a training technique in which you give 100% effort through quick, intense bursts of exercise, followed by short, and sometimes active recovery. You will burn more fat and calories in the 24 hours after a HIIT workout than you do after a steady-pace run.

Weight loss studies have shown that both weight training and HIIT workouts allow you to preserve hard-earned muscle while ensuring most of the weight lost comes from fat stores. results.description:
People of API!

Live streaming at: gotomeeting.com/join/[masked]

The topic of the night is OAuth, namely how to use OAuth2 Scopes to make sure that calls made to your API conform to security policies. Once you have security policies in place, how do you test the final result?

We are pleased to welcome two experts from the API community, Chris Riley of HKM Consulting and Ole Lensmar of SmartBear. We will also have beer and some eats from The Boston Burger Company.

7:00pm - Chris Riley of HKM Consulting will present

"Surf-ing OAuth Scopes in WSO2 API Manager"

As the production of APIs increase within organizations and service providers, the need to support third party access becomes important. In addition the requirement to support a large number of consumers is also a challenge. OAuth2 is a standard that has become prominent in the platforms we leverage heavily today (i.e. Google, Facebook, LinkedIn, Twitter) in both authentication and authorization of resources to very large developer communities. 

In this demonstration, Chris will dig deeper into an example using WSO2 API Manager and Surf (OAuth2 reference resource server) to illustrate OAuth2 and OAuth2 scopes.

7:45 - Ole Lensmar of SmartBear will present

"Testing API Behaviors with Gherkin and TestServer"

As testing of APIs follows the general trend of creating tests through code as part of development efforts – a code-driven approach to test both REST and SOAP apis is increasingly popular in API implementation projects. Pair that with the desire to involve non-technical stakeholders in the requirement process - and you will often end up with a BDD driven approach to API implementation and verification – using frameworks like Cucumber and SpecFlow. Ready! API TestServer aims to provide a scalable and distributed solution for teams that are adopting a code-driven approach to API testing, leveraging the power of the SoapUI API testing engine on any platform, language or framework – and with a rich set of ecosystem components tying into Cucumber, Maven, Node, etc. 

This demonstration will show you the core capabilities of TestServer and how it ties in with these frameworks to make API testing an integral part of the development process.
results.how_to_find_us: bit.ly/smartbear-directions || SmartBear is in the building diagonal to the Lego giraffe, entrance is mid block across from the Paint Bar.
results.name: Ensure API Policies with OAuth and BDD Testing

results.description:
Please join us for pizza, networking and we'll have 2 speakers that will talk through:

1) Spark

2) EclairJS

3) Jupyter Notebooks

We'll start at 6:30pm with food and time for networking, and also to give people time to arrive before we start the talks.

Our presenters will be Brian Burns and Adam Peller of IBM. 

Brian will be disscussng EclairJS. The EclairJS project aims to combine Node.js and Apache Spark to enable a new generation of highly scalable web applications backed with fast and scalable data analytics. It also aims to provide the Node.js and JavaScript development communities with an entry-point into the world of big data computing engines which previously required development in languages such as Java and Scala.

Adam will give an overview of the notebook paradigm which has quickly become a popular environment for data scientists.  Combining human-readable content with computer code in the cloud, notebooks provide both a working environment and a recorded document for sharing data analysis.  A demonstration of the Jupyter Notebook (formerly IPython) will be given.


Speaker Bios:

Brian Burns is a Senior Software Engineer in IBM's Emerging Technologies Group (ET).  Brian has worked in E.T. since joining IBM in 1998.  Over the last several years he has worked on several projects in the area of cloud and big data analytics using technologies such as Apache Spark and Apache Storm.  Currently Brian is the project lead of EclairJS.

Adam Peller's info can be found at https://www.linkedin.com/in/apeller

Among the major benefit of this version will be the ability to leverage Coveo Cloud indexing platform making it much simpler to deploy and manage. It will also leverage machine learning to automatically tune relevance based on visitors behaviors (RevealTM). 

This session will be led by Nicolas Bordeleau, Coveo for Sitecore Product Manager, and will demonstrate how the Cloud edition works from a technical point of view. We are also looking for early adopters and feedback, so come join us to discuss this new version of the product.


Nicolas Bordeleau, Product Manager @ Coveo

Nicolas serves as Coveo's Product Manager for Coveo for Sitecore. With over 10 years of experience in the search industry including 7 years as a software engineer, Nicolas has a keen understanding of developers’ needs related to search products and has applied this knowledge to developing award-winning products that fulfill those needs in innovative ways. 

Nicolas received a B.S. in Computer Engineering from Sherbrooke University. He lives in Quebec with his wife and two children. Aside from his professional interests, Nicolas enjoys technology and sports, specifically skiing and snowboarding.

I will happily belay those who have not climbed before up until 7 PM, but then it's really important to know how to belay and to take the belay test that starts at 7 PM. You can rejoin the group after taking the belay test.

For those of you who already know how to belay, no need to take the class, you just need to pass this gym's belay test when you arrive.

Membership: $89/month

Adult Day Pass: $22

Belay class: $15 (free for members)

I'm looking into whether there is a place nearby to grab a bite or drink at the end of the night. If you have a place in mind, please let me know.

I'll send a message letting you know what color shirt and pants I am wearing incase you arrive late and want to search for us. Wednesday, March 30th, 6:59pm ... (actually) 

Harvard Book Store - 1256 Massachusetts Ave., Cambridge

:: :: ::

Harvard Book Store welcomes National Book Critics Circle Award–winning biographer SARAH BAKEWELL for a discussion of her latest book, At the Existentialist Café: Freedom, Being, and Apricot Cocktails with Jean-Paul Sartre, Simone de Beauvoir, Albert Camus, Martin Heidegger, Maurice Merleau-Ponty and Others.About At the Existentialist Café

From the bestselling author of How to Live, At the Existentialist Café is a spirited account of one of the twentieth century’s major intellectual movements and the revolutionary thinkers who came to shape it.

Paris, 1933: three contemporaries meet over apricot cocktails at the Bec-de-Gaz bar on the rue Montparnasse. They are the young Jean-Paul Sartre, Simone de Beauvoir, and longtime friend Raymond Aron, a fellow philosopher who raves to them about a new conceptual framework from Berlin called Phenomenology. “You see,” he says, “if you are a phenomenologist you can talk about this cocktail and make philosophy out of it!” 

It was this simple phrase that would ignite a movement, inspiring Sartre to integrate Phenomenology into his own French, humanistic sensibility, thereby creating an entirely new philosophical approach inspired by themes of radical freedom, authentic being, and political activism. This movement would sweep through the jazz clubs and cafés of the Left Bank before making its way across the world as Existentialism. 

Featuring not only philosophers, but also playwrights, anthropologists, convicts, and revolutionaries, At the Existentialist Café follows the existentialists’ story, from the first rebellious spark through the Second World War, to its role in postwar liberation movements such as anticolonialism, feminism, and gay rights. Interweaving biography and philosophy, it is the epic account of passionate encounters - fights, love affairs, mentorships, rebellions, and long partnerships - and a vital investigation into what the existentialists have to offer us today, at a moment when we are once again confronting the major questions of freedom, global responsibility, and human authenticity in a fractious and technology-driven world.

"Bakewell brilliantly explains 20th-century existentialism through the extraordinary careers of the philosophers who devoted their lives and work to 'the task of responsible alertness' and 'questions of human identity, purpose, and freedom.' Through vivid characterizations and a clear distillation of dense philosophical concepts, Bakewell embeds the story of existentialism in the 'story of a whole European century,' dramatizing its central debates of authenticity, rebellion, freedom, and responsibility."  - Publishers Weekly 

Purchase the Book: Featured event books will be for sale at the event for 20% off. Thank you for supporting this author series with your purchases.

General Info: (617)[masked] - [masked] 

Media Inquiries: (617)[masked] x1 - [masked] 

Accessibility Inquiries: [masked]

results.description:
The hosting duties for the regular Wednesday Night Gaming are being handled by a rotating cast of regulars who are helping out the Glass-Chewing Leader of the Cartel.

Wednesday Night Gaming is our more-or-less weekly free-for-all of strategy gaming goodness downstairs at the Porter Square Panera. There's rarely a set agenda for these events but you are welcome and encouraged to hash out a plan beforehand in comments if you've got something you're dying to play. Nonetheless, you are not required to bring a game to play -- our only requirement is that you bring an open mind!

The event officially begins at 7 PM but people often trickle in early, so you're welcome to sit down to a filler game to get warmed up, or arrange to meet a little early if you've got a group looking to tackle an extra-meaty game.

Please be aware that Panera has been quite gracious about hosting us with minimal fuss -- in order to keep things this way, please respect the hardworking people who work there and, especially, their desire to get out after a long shift.

We'll see you at the gaming table!
results.name: Wednesday Gaming In Porter Square

results.description:
JP Comics & Games in Jamaica Plain is now running a table for players interested in the newly-begun season of D&D 5e weekly Encounters every Wednesday from 7-9.

"Unearth the Deception" and help stop the forces of Elemental Evil from plunging the Sword Coast into chaos. Designed to take players from level 1 to level 5 by the time the season ends in August, this is a great way to (re)introduce yourself to D&D's current edition and get immersed in a storyline that harks back to the origins of the game.

Pre-generated characters are available, as is help to build your own, so feel free to drop in or contact Ted Atkinson if you'd like more information.

results.description:
This event pertains to the general beekeeping community, and is not an official BABA event.

Please join us to receive a very special guest, Michael Joshin Thiele, Founder of Gaia Bees, who advocate for a fundamental shift in Apiculture and develops new practices toward a bee-centric approach. Michael is coming to the East Coast for the first time as a participant in a 2 day intensive at the Harvard Divinity School on The Spirit of Sustainable Agriculture, so we are very honored to have him gather with us for an evening.

Michael Joshin Thiele is leading an innovative approach within the biodynamic apiculture movement and teaches in the United States and abroad. Gaia Bees is engaged into the research of wild Apis Mellifera and new dimensions of apiculture in a sociocultural, agricultural and spiritual context.  In the last decade, Michael has been involved with the creation of Honeybee sanctuaries and refuges as a means of protection and education. The most recent project is the Honeybee Sanctuary & Refuge at Green Gulch Farm. 

The underlying concept of a “Landscape Apiarium” is the leading principle in this bee-centric approach.   In 2013, he worked as a biodynamic consultant for the USDA in the Dominican Republic.  His work is documented in various national and international magazines, books and film documentaries (“Queen of the Sun”). For one of the most recent interviews (2015) go to: 

Michael will explore how the bio-integrity of Honeybee nests can inform and heal our apiaries and landscapes, and how the wisdom of Honeybees can be an inspiration for the evolution of new paradigms of life.
results.name: Michael Joshin Thiele, Founder of Gaia Bees, at Follow the Honey

results.description:
Join the Boston Austrian Economics Group as we embark upon Chapter 19: The Rate of Interest, of the Austrian classic; "Human Action: A Treatise on Economics," by Ludwig von Mises. The group will discuss the weekly reading and questions.

Please note the readings are not required to attend our meeting, but are recommended. As always, anyone interested in economics is welcome.

Tony C's Sports Bar and Grill has plenty of parking and is accessible via the Orange Line "Assembly" stop. Our group meets in the private room at the back of the restaurant, the reservation is under Austrian Economics Group.

Please feel free to call Natalya @[masked], our Director of Events, with any questions.

READING: Part 4, Chapter 19: The Rate of Interest
https://mises.org/library/human-action-0/html/p/810


QUESTIONS: 1) What is the definition of originary interest?

2) Does the serviceableness of the factors of production explain the interest earned by someone who invests in them? Why not?

3) How does originary interest manifest itself in the market economy?

4) Why would originary interest exist in a very primitive state of affairs, and is this concept still valid in a socialist commonwealth?

5) What does scarcity imply with regard to the technological improvement of production processes?

6) What are the defnitions of plain and capitalist savings?

7) What is the essential deficiency of the static system as Schumpeter dsecribes it?

8) Can interest be abolished by law, how about interest payments?

9) What was the British classical meaning of "proft?" What is the modern understanding?

10) Why do the activities of the entrepreneurs tend toward the establishment of a uniform rate of originary interest?

11) If a bond is issued with a contractually fixed rate of interest, what happens if conditions change during the life of the bond such that people now discount the future more heavily?
results.name: THE RATE OF INTEREST
